A. Toxins are removed from the bloodstream by the liver.
B. The stomach signals for the production of gastric juices.
C. Food molecules are transported to the organs of the body.
D. Gases are exchanged between the lungs and blood vessels.
examples.target: D. Gases are exchanged between the lungs and blood vessels.

examples.input:
Animals depend on plants for many things, including food. What do plants depend on from animals?
A. energy for photosynthesis
B. pest control
C. carbon dioxide
D. oxygen

Less force is required to launch a spaceship from the surface of the Moon than to launch an identical ship from the surface of Earth because
A. the Moon has a smaller surface area than Earth.
B. the mass of an object on Earth is greater than on the Moon.
C. the gravitational field of the Moon is less than that of Earth.
D. the atmosphere of the Moon is much thinner than that of Earth.
examples.target: C. the gravitational field of the Moon is less than that of Earth.

examples.input:
Two of Earth's plates pushed together, and the ground moved. What happened?
A. an earthquake
B. a landslide
C. a volcano
D. an avalanche

Which of these were formed by glaciers that flowed through the Ruby Mountain region in northeastern Nevada?
A. lakes
B. deserts
C. volcanic necks
D. V-shaped valleys

A student prepared the following list of characteristics about a cellular organelle. present in animal cells present in plant cells helps make energy available to the cell Which of the following cellular structures is the student describing?
A. cell wall
B. chloroplast
C. mitochondrion
D. nucleus

Brian knows deserts get less rain than other ecosystems. However, he also knows that plants can survive in the desert. Which characteristic of a plant most likely helps it live in a desert?
A. the ability to store water
B. the ability to attract insects
C. the ability to stop predators
D. the ability to drop its leaves
examples.target: A. the ability to store water

examples.input:
After a volcanic eruption, it takes a long time for large ecosystems to fully recover. Which statement best explains why the development takes so long?
A. Space is limited for growth.
B. The quality of light is low.
C. Soil must be created.
D. Minerals are destroyed.

The atomic number of an element refers to the number of
A. electrons in the outer shell.
B. neutrons in the outer shell.
C. electrons in the nucleus.
D. protons in the nucleus.

In an ecosystem, not all of the energy that is available is used by the organisms. Some energy becomes unavailable before it can be transferred to organisms in the next trophic level. How does the energy most likely become unavailable?
A. The energy is stored as food.
B. The energy is dissipated as heat.
C. The energy is trapped in dead organisms.
D. The energy is moved to another ecosystem.
examples.target: B. The energy is dissipated as heat.

examples.input:
Which of the following is a direct result of Earth's tilt on its axis?
A. tides
B. seasons
C. weather
D. gravity

Tony always drinks water before and after his long bike rides. Why does his body need water when he exercises?
A. Drinking water after exercise allows the body to sleep.
B. Drinking water after exercise helps to replace lost fluids.
C. Drinking water before exercise helps increase the heart rate.
D. Drinking water before exercise prevents the body from sweating.
examples.target: B. Drinking water after exercise helps to replace lost fluids.

examples.input:
On a field trip in a wooded area, you see a small, strange object. You wonder whether is is a live animal. The best way to find out is to observe the object to see if it
A. has an odor.
B. has separate parts.
C. can make a noise and has a lifelike color.
D. carries out basic life functions.
examples.target: D. carries out basic life functions.

examples.input:
Liquid cooking oil was poured into a container. Which statement best describes a property of the cooking oil after it was poured into the container?
A. Its color changed.
B. Its mass increased.
C. Its volume stayed the same.
D. Its temperature quickly increased.
examples.target: C. Its volume stayed the same.

examples.input:
The Sun heats the atmosphere of Earth unevenly. Which of the following is the most likely result of this uneven heating?
A. Convection in the atmosphere causes a change in air density, resulting in winds.
B. Conduction through the atmosphere causes evaporation to occur over oceans, resulting in rain.
C. Radiation from the Sun will reflect through the atmosphere back into space resulting in cooler evenings.
D. Radiation from the Sun will cause atmospheric moisture to collect over mountain ranges resulting in snowfall.
examples.target: A. Convection in the atmosphere causes a change in air density, resulting in winds.

examples.input:
A 20-N force acts on a 5-kg object at rest. How fast will the object accelerate on a frictionless surface?
A. 4 m/s^2
B. 15 m/s^2
C. 25 m/s^2
D. 100 m/s^2

Increasing and revising scientific knowledge of different types of bacteria will most likely enable scientists to develop ways to
A. help patients spend less time in the emergency room.
B. aid research students who are studying complex organisms.
C. help make medicines from newly discovered plants.
D. develop specialized antibiotics that are directed at single-celled organisms.
examples.target: D. develop specialized antibiotics that are directed at single-celled organisms.

examples.input:
What are produced in both the male and female reproductive systems in humans?
1. sperm
2. nutrients
3. fertilized eggs
4. sex cells

The burning of fossil fuels in cities results in high levels of air pollution. Which urban design would best help reduce air pollution?
A. numerous park areas
B. frequent trash recycling
C. efficient public transportation
D. effective street lighting

Which is an inherited trait?
A. dimples
B. scrapes
C. short hair
D. dirty fingernails

How is xylem similar to phloem in a plant?
A. They both take in water from the soil.
B. They both transport materials through the plant.
C. They both make sugar in the leaves.
D. They both store waste products in the plant cells.
examples.target: B. They both transport materials through the plant.

examples.input:
In a recycling program, people can separate paper from their other trash. The paper is sent to factories and turned into new products. What does paper recycling help conserve the most?
A. air
B. gasoline
C. trees
D. water

Water cycles through three states of matter on Earth. What has the greatest effect on the state of matter of water?
A. tides
B. gravity
C. the sun
D. the moon

Which physical feature exists both on Earth and on the Moon?
A. lakes
B. forests
C. mountains
D. clouds

Animals and plants are made up of a number of different chemical elements. What happens to all of these elements when animals and plants die?
A. They die with the animal or plant.
B. They evaporate into the atmosphere.
C. They are recycled back into the environment.
D. They change into different elements.
examples.target: C. They are recycled back into the environment.

examples.input:
Students are comparing different rocks. What do all rocks have in common?
A. Rocks are made of one or more minerals.
B. Rocks are made of two or more elements.
C. Rocks are made of magma and sediments.
D. Rocks are made of sand changed by pressure.
examples.target: A. Rocks are made of one or more minerals.

examples.input:
What is the most likely result of large-scale agricultural fertilization on aquatic systems?
A. increased fish populations
B. more biodiversity over time
C. less oxygen available for fish
D. reduced water levels
examples.target: C. less oxygen available for fish

examples.input:
In order for magma to be converted to igneous rock, which actions must occur?
A. melting and cooling
B. heating and pressure
C. weathering and erosion
D. crystallization and cooling

Trees start as seeds and grow into mature trees that produce more seeds. This pattern represents a
A. food chain
B. life cycle
C. food supply
D. life span

Which sequence identifies the levels of organization of body structures in a human from simplest to most complex?
1. cell -> organ -> tissue -> organ system
2. organ system -> cell -> tissue -> organ
3. tissue -> organ -> organ system -> cell
4. cell -> tissue -> organ -> organ system

A cell completes the synthesization of a protein by adding a carbohydrate to the protein's structure. At which site in the cell is the carbohydrate added?
A. the nucleus
B. a ribosome
C. a mitochondrion
D. the Golgi apparatus

All atoms of an element have in their nuclei the same number of
A. electrons.
B. isotopes.
C. molecules.
D. protons.

Henry learned that without the right kind of energy, plants cannot survive. What form of energy is used by plants to perform photosynthesis?
A. electrical
B. light
C. mechanical
D. wind

As a corn plant ages, its leaves grow. Which process is directly responsible for the growth of these leaves?
A. the division of cells in the plant
B. the release of oxygen from the plant
C. the absorption of carbon dioxide in the stem
D. the transportation of nutrients from the roots
examples.target: A. the division of cells in the plant

examples.input:
Which scientist is best known for research that led to the modern understanding of the atom?
A. Newton
B. Dalton
C. Galileo
D. Copernicus

Which body system typically recognizes, attacks, and destroys foreign cells or substances that may cause disease?
A. digestive
B. excretory
C. immune
D. respiratory

Cell membranes allow some molecules to move freely across the membrane, while other molecules are restricted. Which term best describes this capability of a cell membrane?
A. semipermeable
B. impervious
C. resilient
D. unyielding

Which statement describes the transfer of energy when an ice cube is placed in a cup of hot tea?
A. Heat flows from the tea to the ice.
B. Cold flows from the ice to the tea.
C. Cold flows from the ice, and heat flows from the tea.
D. Heat flows simultaneously between the ice and the tea.
examples.target: A. Heat flows from the tea to the ice.

examples.input:
Which is the most cooperative relationship between species?
A. mutualism
B. predation
C. parasitism
D. coexistence

A dog rolls over and receives a treat. The dog rolls over again. This is an example of
A. learned behavior.
B. adaptive behavior.
C. inherited behavior.
D. instinctive behavior.

Which type of rock is formed when particles are compacted and cemented together?
A. igneous
B. metallic
C. metamorphic
D. sedimentary

Tree roots can grow into rock and break it apart. Water can freeze in the cracks of rock, causing it to break apart. How are these two processes alike?
A. Both are forces.
B. Both affect weather.
C. Both form new kinds of rock.
D. Both are forms of weathering.
examples.target: D. Both are forms of weathering.

examples.input:
Energy is absorbed and released through endothermic and exothermic processes. Which is an example of an exothermic process?
A. ice melting
B. ice sublimating
C. water evaporating
D. water freezing

Where is most fresh (non-salty) water on Earth located?
A. oceans
B. rivers
C. lakes
D. polar ice caps

When a molecule is separated into its component parts, it forms
A. compounds.
B. atoms.
C. protons.
D. ions.

The universe is believed to be approximately 14 billion years old. As a result of gravitational attraction, which most likely developed first after the Big Bang?
A. a planet
B. a comet
C. a moon
D. a star

Which is a function of the cardiovascular system?
A. to move water throughout the body
B. to provide structural support for the body
C. to eliminate waste from the body
D. to transport gases throughout the body
examples.target: D. to transport gases throughout the body

examples.input:
When a fern reproduces with spores, the offspring
A. will be genetically identical to the parent plant.
B. will be better able to adapt to the environment.
C. will have half the genetic materials of the parent plant.
D. will have twice the genetic materials of the parent plant.
examples.target: A. will be genetically identical to the parent plant.

examples.input:
The process of water changing from its liquid state to a gas in the water cycle is known as
A. precipitation.
B. evaporation.
C. condensation.
D. translation.

In which situation would osmosis most likely occur in cells?
A. across a permeable membrane that separates solutions of the same concentration
B. across a permeable membrane that separates solutions of different concentrations
C. across a nonpermeable membrane that separates solutions of the same concentration
D. across a nonpermeable membrane that separates solutions of different concentrations
examples.target: B. across a permeable membrane that separates solutions of different concentrations

examples.input:
A scientist is watching birds from far away. Which object is the scientist most likely using to watch the birds?
A. goggles
B. binoculars
C. sunglasses
D. microscope

Studies of earthquake waves have helped scientists determine the
1. structure of Earth's interior
2. depth of the oceans
3. cause of dinosaur extinction
4. age of Earth

Needles on a cactus plant are actually leaves. This needle shape helps the plant survive by
A. catching food.
B. preventing water loss.
C. staying in place.
D. reproducing.

Compost piles have many parts, such as leaves, moisture, vegetables, and microorganisms. Which part of a compost pile breaks down materials and adds nutrients to the soil?
A. leaves
B. moisture
C. vegetables
D. microorganisms

A piece of pine wood floats on the surface of a lake because the water exerts
A. an upward force equal to the weight of the wood.
B. a downward force equal to the weight of the wood.
C. an upward force equal to the weight of the displacement water.
D. a downward force equal to the weight of the displacement water.
examples.target: C. an upward force equal to the weight of the displacement water.

examples.input:
All living things contain which element?
A. helium.
B. sodium.
C. copper.
D. carbon.

A student performed an experiment to see how long it would take for a cup of water to freeze. Which information would another student most likely need in order to perform the same experiment?
A. the time to begin
B. the volume of the cup
C. the temperature of the ice
D. the type of thermometer to use
examples.target: B. the volume of the cup

examples.input:
A student wants to know which type of soil holds the most water. Which action should the student most likely do to answer the question?
A. compare how the soils are alike
B. put the soils into different groups
C. record the weight of the soil
D. watch how quickly the soil drains
examples.target: D. watch how quickly the soil drains

examples.input:
Which of these is required to support the theory of star formation?
A. laws passed by the government
B. Internet sites discussing star formation
C. pictures of stars of different ages
D. evaluation of data by many scientists
examples.target: D. evaluation of data by many scientists

examples.input:
The frequency of a wave is measured in
A. hertz.
B. meters.
C. hertz/second.
D. meters/minute.

Which process causes the fastest changes to the surface of Earth?
A. a large glacier forming on a mountain
B. strong winds wearing away a rock cliff
C. a major earthquake happening in a mountain range
D. many waves on a lake moving pebbles onto a beach
examples.target: C. a major earthquake happening in a mountain range

examples.input:
Organisms contribute to the water cycle mainly through the process of
A. irrigation.
B. evaporation.
C. precipitation.
D. transpiration.

Which of these tools is most helpful to a scientist observing very small bacteria?
A. ruler
B. telescope
C. microscope
D. meter stick

Apple slices were divided evenly between two identical metal boxes. A lighted 20-watt incandescent light bulb was placed in box A, and a lighted 20-watt fluorescent light was placed in box B. The apple slices in box A dried faster than those in box B because
A. fluorescent light is a luminous light.
B. incandescent light produces more heat.
C. fluorescent light has a lower frequency.
D. incandescent light causes a chemical reaction.
examples.target: B. incandescent light produces more heat.

examples.input:
What season is it in the United States when the South Pole is tilted toward the Sun?
A. summer
B. fall
C. winter
D. spring

Which of these colors of visible light has the shortest wavelength?
A. red
B. green
C. violet
D. yellow

Which of the following units best represents the density of an object?
A. kg
B. hr
C. m/s^2
D. g/cm^3

Which statement below best explains why several fossils of sea organisms were discovered buried deep in an area of dry land?
A. The fossils changed locations.
B. The area had a shift in climate.
C. The land was once underwater.
D. A glacier once covered the area.
examples.target: C. The land was once underwater.

examples.input:
Last year Steve was shorter than his brother. This year Steve is taller than his brother. What cell process is directly responsible for Steve's growth?
A. diffusion
B. mitosis
C. osmosis
D. respiration

In which state are molecules of a substance arranged in the most orderly way?
A. gas
B. liquid
C. plasma
D. solid

Weather stations built in urban areas can be influenced by the human-made structures that surround these stations. Some of these weather stations used to determine mean temperatures in the United States have had the validity of the data questioned. Which human-produced effect could these urban weather stations be measuring?
A. heat island
B. rain shadow
C. land breeze
D. cold front

How is the mass of an atom calculated?
A. add the number of protons to the number of electrons
B. add the number of protons to the number of neutrons
C. subtract the number of protons from the number of neutrons
D. subtract the number of electrons from the sum of protons and neutrons
examples.target: B. add the number of protons to the number of neutrons

examples.input:
Over a long period, some flowering plants have become dependent on honey bees for pollination. In recent years, a form of mite has infected and killed the honey bees in many areas of the country. Since this has happened, the once bee-dependent plants with the best chance of surviving are those that
A. grow taller so that the few remaining honey bees will find them.
B. change their flowers so that wind will fertilize them.
C. have always attracted many other insects as wells as honey bees.
D. have seeds that stay alive for a long time in the environment.
examples.target: C. have always attracted many other insects as wells as honey bees.

examples.input:
Which of these atomic structures has the least amount of mass?
A. an ion
B. a proton
C. a neutron
D. an electron

An increase of carbon dioxide in Earth's atmosphere is most likely to have which effect?
A. decreased variations in day length
B. increased average air temperature
C. increased burn rate for incoming meteoroids
D. decreased rate of ozone layer destruction

Which of the following is an inherited human trait?
A. eye color
B. sleep patterns
C. sense of balance
D. sense of humor

Snow turns to liquid water when it
A. freezes.
B. melts.
C. condenses.
D. evaporates.

Which energy source is nonrenewable?
1. sunlight
2. biomass
3. wind
4. fossil fuel

The Moon is in orbit around Earth. What keeps the Moon from changing its orbit?
A. friction
B. gravity
C. weight
D. rotation

Which form of water, when present in the atmosphere, is most likely to contribute to global warming?
A. cloud
B. rain
C. vapor
D. snow

Which statement explains why ducklings follow their mother when swimming across a pond?
A. Survival behavior is acquired by interaction with the parent duck.
B. Survival behavior is learned by interacting with their environment.
C. Inherited behavior is genetically obtained through their environment.
D. Inherited behavior is genetically passed on from parents to offspring.
examples.target: D. Inherited behavior is genetically passed on from parents to offspring.

examples.input:
Some students measure the mass of a small pile of leaves before and after the leaves decompose. Each time the students measure the mass, they place a container with the decomposing leaves on a balance. Before recording the mass of the leaves, the students must do which of the following?
A. Subtract the mass of the container
B. Add leaves from other plants to the container
C. Allow the leaves to settle in the container for a few days
D. Use a metric ruler to measure the volume of the container
examples.target: A. Subtract the mass of the container

examples.input:
Ava conducted an experiment to determine respiratory rates during different activities. She counted the number of breaths per minute. Ava noted that the number of breaths increases as physical activity increases. Why is there an increase in the number of breaths per minute as activity increases?
A. As activity increases, more oxygen is exhaled.
B. As activity increases, breathing becomes more efficient.
C. As activity increases, the oxygen needs of cells increase.
D. As activity increases, the rate of the heart beating increases.
examples.target: C. As activity increases, the oxygen needs of cells increase.

examples.input:
The temperature in a classroom is 15°C (59°F). The teacher turns the thermostat to 20°C (68°F) and keeps the door closed. Which of the following statements best describes the change that occurs as the temperature in the room increases to 20°C?
A. Cold air molecules collide to generate heat energy.
B. Cold energy in the room transforms into heat energy.
C. The room becomes warmer as heat energy is added to the room.
D. The room becomes warmer as cold energy is pushed out of the room.
examples.target: C. The room becomes warmer as heat energy is added to the room.

examples.input:
A flat piece of paper has a mass of 5 grams. When the paper is crumpled into a ball, the mass of the crumpled paper is
A. much more than that of the flat paper.
B. slightly more than that of the flat paper.
C. the same as that of the flat paper.
D. slightly less than that of the flat paper.
examples.target: C. the same as that of the flat paper.

examples.input:
Minerals are used for making many things including jewelry, chalk, and concrete. Where do we get the minerals needed to make these things?
A. from air
B. from wood
C. from rocks
D. from crops

Scientists have observed that, even within the same nest, some young birds call louder than others. Which describes how a louder cry helps to ensure survival?
A. Lung capacity is increased.
B. Exposure to bacteria is increased.
C. Parents are able to identify the nest.
D. Parents respond by giving more food.
examples.target: D. Parents respond by giving more food.

examples.input:
Two galaxies are interacting with each other. What is the force that draws these two galaxies toward each other?
A. friction
B. gravity
C. electricity
D. magnetism

Which procedure correctly describes materials combining?
A. Salt and sand are added to hot water and stirred making a mixture.
B. Oil and water are placed in a sealed bottle and shaken making a compound.
C. Sugar and water are added to flour and cooked in an oven making an element.
D. Soil and water are shaken in a container and left to separate forming two elements.
examples.target: A. Salt and sand are added to hot water and stirred making a mixture.

examples.input:
Plants growing in a pond release a gas that fish need to survive. Which gas do the plants release that fish use?
A. helium
B. hydrogen
C. nitrogen
D. oxygen

A ball rolling on the ground is observed to slow down and stop. Based on Newton's first law of motion, what is the best conclusion?
A. An object in motion eventually stops.
B. The ball must have been going slightly uphill.
C. The ball did not have enough mass to keep going.
D. There must have been an outside force acting on the ball.
examples.target: D. There must have been an outside force acting on the ball.

examples.input:
What is the chemical formula for carbon dioxide?
A. CO
B. CO2
C. C
D. O2

A student rubs his hands together to warm them. His hands get warm due to
A. friction
B. gravity
C. magnetism
D. sound

Scientists studying migrating birds and homing pigeons have discovered that they navigate by monitoring differences in the intensity and inclination of Earth's magnetic field. Special cells in bird beaks can detect these changes as the birds fly over Earth's surface. Which metal did the scientists find in the cells that birds use as a magnetometer?
A. iron
B. gold
C. mercury
D. aluminum

A scientist found a fossil of an organism that had gills. When the organism was living, the area in which it lived was most likely covered by ___.
A. forest
B. grassland
C. bare rock
D. water

Which is the best way to help protect the environment?
A. wash hands before each meal
B. do a science project about energy
C. ride a bike to school instead of riding in a car
D. pack a lunch instead of buying a school lunch
examples.target: C. ride a bike to school instead of riding in a car

examples.input:
An electric motor is designed to turn electrical energy into ___.
A. solar energy
B. potential energy
C. static electricity
D. mechanical energy

If a student playing the drums hits the drums with greater force, the sound would be
A. quieter.
B. louder.
C. lower in pitch.
D. higher in pitch.

As the loudness of a sound wave increases, which will also increase?
A. amplitude
B. frequency
C. velocity
D. wavelength

Telescopes use lenses to observe distant objects such as stars. Which term best describes what happens when lenses bend and concentrate light?
A. reflecting
B. polarizing
C. diffracting
D. refracting

Which of these must occur when a substance goes through a chemical change?
A. The substance gets larger.
B. The substance changes phases.
C. The substance changes shape.
D. The substance forms a new substance.
examples.target: D. The substance forms a new substance.

examples.input:
Scientists use ice cores to identify and explain previous climatic trends. By correlating climatic conditions recorded in the ice, with solid, nonsnow particles also found in the ice, scientists can help to predict the climatic impact of which phenomena?
A. atmospheric carbon dioxide concentration changes
B. radioactive decay rate changes in the outer core
C. volcanic eruptions
D. magnetic pole reversals

Coal, oil, and natural gas have high potential energies, which makes them valuable energy resources. In order to benefit from the energy available in these fossil fuels, the potential energy is converted most directly into which type of energy?
A. chemical
B. electrical
C. solar
D. thermal

What change would occur if Earth's rate of rotation significantly increased?
A. The year would be shorter.
B. The year would be longer.
C. The day would be shorter.
D. The day would be longer.
examples.target: C. The day would be shorter.

examples.input:
Humans can do many things to impact the environment. Which of these is an example of how humans negatively impact the environment?
A. planting more trees
B. burning less fossil fuel
C. reducing beach erosion
D. increasing water runoff

Eyeglasses help a nearsighted person see as a result of
A. absorption.
B. diffraction.
C. reflection.
D. refraction.

A student measures the rising temperature of heated water for 20 minutes in two-minute intervals. Which of these tools will best help the student organize the data?
A. flow chart
B. pie chart
C. data table
D. bar graph

A rock formation in a land area contains fossils. Over time, tremendous heat and pressure change the formation to produce a harder rock formation without fossils. Which change in rock type has occurred in this land area?
A. Igneous rock has turned into sedimentary rock.
B. Igneous rock has turned into metamorphic rock.
C. Sedimentary rock has turned into igneous rock.
D. Sedimentary rock has turned into metamorphic rock.
examples.target: D. Sedimentary rock has turned into metamorphic rock.

examples.input:
Which is not an inherited trait in humans?
A. blue eyes
B. long fingers
C. calloused hands
D. attached earlobes

The wind helps many plants reproduce by ___.
A. cooling the plants
B. giving the plants moisture
C. spreading the plants' pollen
D. strengthening the plants' root systems

The human hearing range is 20-20,000 hertz. A sound Peggy heard was measured at 15,000 hertz. Which characteristic best describes the sound wave that Peggy heard?
A. fast speed
B. high frequency
C. large amplitude
D. long wavelength

A student is asked to measure the distance from the floor to the ceiling in a classroom. Which unit of measurement should the student most likely use to accurately measure this distance?
A. liter
B. kiloliter
C. meter
D. kilometer

Which of the following explains why elements, such as carbon and oxygen, that are used in organic molecules are not permanently removed from the environment?
A. They are replenished by sunlight.
B. They are cycled through ecosystems.
C. They are replaced by volcanic eruptions.
D. They are produced constantly from nutrients.
examples.target: B. They are cycled through ecosystems.

examples.input:
A student is measuring the speed at which a ball rolls down a ramp. Which unit of measurement is the student most likely using to describe the speed of the ball?
A. meter per liter
B. seconds per gram
C. milligrams per liter
D. centimeters per second

Marta and Roger are comparing how long it takes two different types of seeds to sprout. They plant both types of seeds in similar pots, place them in a sunny window, and water them daily. If they want to conduct their investigation correctly, which information is most important to record?
A. the depth of the soil
B. the temperature of the water
C. the number of days until the seeds sprout
D. the size of pot used for growing the seeds
examples.target: C. the number of days until the seeds sprout

examples.input:
Deposition of sediment will most likely form a
A. cave.
B. delta.
C. river.
D. mountain.

During a space mission, scientists will send experiments for the astronauts to conduct in space. In many cases, scientists have made predictions about the outcome of the experiment. Why do astronauts perform the experiment if the results have already been predicted?
A. to obtain data to test a hypothesis
B. to make a complete observation
C. to make a report of the procedures
D. to make a hypothesis understandable
examples.target: A. to obtain data to test a hypothesis

examples.input:
Approximately 14,000 years ago, the climate in North America began to warm rapidly. At the same time, human hunters migrated to the continent. Which of these most likely resulted from a combination of these two factors?
A. a reduction in the rate of species change
B. an increase in the rate of large mammal extinctions
C. an increase in the amount of interspecies cooperation
D. a reduction in the total number of small parasitic insects
examples.target: B. an increase in the rate of large mammal extinctions

examples.input:
Which is an SI unit for density?
A. lb
B. kg
C. lb/ft^3
D. kg/m^3

In the United States, each day the Sun appears to
A. rise in the west and set in the east.
B. rise in the east and set in the west.
C. rise in the north and set in the south.
D. rise in the south and set in the north.
examples.target: B. rise in the east and set in the west.

examples.input:
Which substance is magnetic and conducts heat?
A. wood
B. plastic
C. iron
D. paper

During a biochemical reaction, pyruvate (C3H4O3) is converted into carbon dioxide (CO2) and water (H2O). In what cellular organelle does this biochemical reaction occur?
A. nucleus
B. cytoplasm
C. mitochondria
D. endoplasmic reticulum

A student fails to eat a balanced diet over a period of time. This lack of a balanced diet can lead to
1. selective breeding
2. dynamic equilibrium
3. extinction
4. disease

In 1989, an oil spill off the coast of Alaska led to a decline in the population of many organisms. Which other population was most likely affected by the drop in population of the fish, otters, and seals?
A. deer
B. eagles
C. frogs
D. snakes

Which of these is the best reason for exercising on space flights?
A. to increase strength for moving around in the cabin
B. to keep from becoming overweight on a space mission
C. to minimize the loss of muscle mass due to microgravity
D. to ensure that bodily fluids do not tend to collect in the feet
examples.target: C. to minimize the loss of muscle mass due to microgravity

examples.input:
With the development of the microscope, scientists were able to see cells for the first time. Why was it difficult to view cells without a microscope?
A. Cells are small.
B. Cells are alive.
C. Cells move quickly.
D. Cells have an electrical charge.

Fertilizers can enable farmers to grow the same crop in a field for several years in a row. Farmers who use less fertilizer often rotate their crops by planting the crop one year and legumes, such as beans and clover, the following year. Fertilizer use and crop rotation with legumes both increase the availability of which of the following nutrients in soil?
A. calcium
B. nitrogen
C. oxygen
D. protein

Which two processes occur during the life spans of all animals?
A. hibernation and migration
B. growth and development
C. changing color and shedding fur
D. building nests and communication

Which of the following is true regarding the properties of an air mass?
A. An air mass is warmer at the leading edge and cooler at the trailing edge.
B. An air mass has similar temperature and moisture properties throughout it.
C. An air mass is cooler near the edges and has greater moisture near the center.
D. An air mass has greater moisture near the edges and is cooler near the center.
examples.target: B. An air mass has similar temperature and moisture properties throughout it.

examples.input:
When entire communities in an ecosystem change over time, it is known as
A. migration.
B. extinction.
C. overpopulation.
D. ecological succession.

What should be added to soil to increase its water retention?
A. pebbles
B. sand
C. rocks
D. clay

A rosebush and a bird are similar because they both
A. are living organisms.
B. need to search for food.
C. make their own food.
D. are non-living organisms.

The mineral quartz naturally forms in various colors. Which difference in quartz formation results in the different colors?
A. pressure at which the processes occurred
B. temperature at which the processes occurred
C. chemical impurities present as the processes occurred
D. amount of time passed since the processes occurred
examples.target: C. chemical impurities present as the processes occurred

examples.input:
What happens to a moist air mass as it moves upward in the atmosphere?
A. It becomes warmer and forms clouds.
B. It becomes cooler and forms clouds.
C. Its temperature remains the same.
D. Its temperature varies greatly.
examples.target: B. It becomes cooler and forms clouds.

examples.input:
Greenhouse gases in the atmosphere absorb infrared radiation from Earth's surface and re-radiates some of it back to Earth. Which of these gases have the most significant impact on the temperature of Earth's atmosphere?
A. nitrogen and argon
B. oxygen and sulfur dioxide
C. carbon dioxide and water vapor
D. hydrochloric acid and hydrogen
examples.target: C. carbon dioxide and water vapor

examples.input:
Volcanoes are considered constructive because they
A. deposit lava.
B. cause erosion.
C. trigger earthquakes.
D. release gases.

What happens to sugar when it is combined with water?
A. it separates
B. it dissolves
C. it floats to the top
D. it becomes warm

Pesticides are chemicals that kill insects. What could happen if the pesticides killed all the pollinators near some apple trees?
A. The trees could not make leaves.
B. The trees could not make flowers.
C. The trees could not make seeds.
D. The trees could not make bark.
examples.target: C. The trees could not make seeds.

examples.input:
Which statement describes the formation of a delta?
A. A large mass of ice and snow accumulates.
B. A mound of sand is built by wind.
C. A low area of land is surrounded by mountains.
D. A mass of sediment is deposited at the mouth of a river.
examples.target: D. A mass of sediment is deposited at the mouth of a river.

examples.input:
Hydrogen and oxygen combine to form water. The water in this reaction is described as
A. an atom
B. a reactant
C. an element
D. a compound

Which of these cell parts store genetic instructions for the entire organism and transfers them from one generation to the next?
A. chloroplasts
B. mitochondria
C. DNA molecules
D. nuclear membranes

Which list describes the particles that make up an atom?
A. nucleus, electrons, and quarks
B. protons, neutron, and electrons
C. ionic bonds, covalent bonds, and ions
D. nucleus, electron cloud, and energy levels

Earth has a limited supply of fresh drinking water. Which method is used to recycle water for humans to use?
A. bottling water
B. dam construction
C. collecting rainwater
D. wastewater treatment

A plover bird eats bits of food that become stuck in a crocodile's teeth without being hurt. The crocodile gets its teeth cleaned and the bird gets food. Which type of relationship exists between the bird and the crocodile?
A. mutualism
B. commensalism
C. parasitism
D. phototropism

What can scientists learn about the past by studying sedimentary rocks?
A. how a species changed over time
B. how animals made a shelter
C. the color of leaves on a plant
D. the number of chambers in a dinosaur's heart
examples.target: A. how a species changed over time

examples.input:
A scientific explanation should include a demonstration of the relationships between
A. measurement, form, and function.
B. changes, interactions, and formulas.
C. logic, evidence, and current knowledge.
D. hypothesis, problem solving, and lab equipment.
examples.target: C. logic, evidence, and current knowledge.

examples.input:
A plant that has traits identical to the parent plant provides evidence that the plant
A. resulted from sexual reproduction.
B. resulted from asexual reproduction.
C. will develop many seeds.
D. will have large leaves.

Which property would best help a student determine if two substances are made of two different elements?
A. mass
B. shape
C. density
D. volume

Evidence of organisms that lived on Earth a long time ago would most likely be found in
A. crystals.
B. lava.
C. sedimentary rock.
D. metamorphic rock.

Which type of energy does a radiator give off ?
A. heat
B. light
C. solar
D. electrical

While hiking through Granville State Forest, a student finds an unusual plant-like organism that appears to lack chlorophyll. When the student examines a sample using a microscope, he sees many cells with cell walls and no chloroplasts. This organism is most likely a member of what Kingdom?
A. Animalia
B. Eubacteria
C. Fungi
D. Protista

A student conducts an experiment to determine the effect soap has on the growth of radish seeds. He puts 30 seeds in three different dishes: one with water, one with a 1% soap solution, and one with a 10% soap solution. Which type of data should he collect?
A. size of seeds and amount of solution used
B. time of day and number of seeds germinated
C. type of detergent and amount of solution used
D. number of seeds germinated and average length of shoot
examples.target: B. time of day and number of seeds germinated

examples.input:
Which of the following statements best describes how the use of interchangeable parts has affected car manufacturing?
A. The number of cars produced has decreased.
B. The need for custom manufacturing has increased.
C. The efficiency of manufacturing plants has increased.
D. The number of countries producing cars has decreased.
examples.target: C. The efficiency of manufacturing plants has increased.

examples.input:
Which quantity must equal zero if a car is moving at a constant rate along a straight line?
A. speed of the car
B. direction of the car
C. energy of the car
D. acceleration of the car

Which widely used energy sources are nonrenewable and also a source of greenhouse gas emissions?
A. wind turbines
B. hydroelectric dams
C. fossil fuels
D. solar cells

Use the information below to answer the question. In solid fuel rockets, a fuel mixture is burned and once the mixture starts burning it cannot be stopped. In liquid fuel rockets, there is a tank of fuel and a tank of oxygen. The burning of the fuel can be stopped by preventing the flow of fuel and oxygen into the combustion chamber. Based on this information, which system is more highly developed in liquid fuel rockets than in solid fuel rockets?
A. propulsion
B. suspension
C. control
D. structure

Some research has shown that the burning of fossil fuels contributes to an effect called global warming, which scientists believe is changing the chemical makeup of Earth's atmosphere. Use of which invention would help lower this effect?
A. electric car
B. digital camera
C. high-speed Internet
D. battery-powered radio

Which food contains the highest percentage of protein?
A. rice
B. dates
C. carrots
D. chicken

When conducting an investigation involving an open flame, it is most important to
A. turn out the lights to see better.
B. smell the product that is being burned.
C. work near the sink to put out possible fires.
D. wear appropriate protective clothing and eyewear.
examples.target: D. wear appropriate protective clothing and eyewear.

examples.input:
In ecosystems where people live, which of the following are most likely to cause an increase in diseases transmitted by water?
A. floods
B. blizzards
C. hailstorms
D. avalanches

Aphids are small insects that sometimes live near ants. The ants protect the aphids from predators. The aphids produce a sweet substance that the ants eat. Which statement describes the relationship between ants and aphids?
A. Both ants and aphids benefit.
B. Both ants and aphids are unaffected.
C. The ants benefit and the aphids are harmed.
D. The aphids benefit and the ants are unaffected.
examples.target: A. Both ants and aphids benefit.

examples.input:
Soil will pack down over time which decreases the ability of the soil to hold water. Which animals would best help the soil hold water?
A. earthworms making tunnels under the surface
B. cattle making depressions with their hooves
C. horses making trenches when they gallop
D. sheep pulling up plants by their roots
examples.target: A. earthworms making tunnels under the surface

examples.input:
At an archaeological dig site, scientists, volunteers, and students collect items used by people living hundreds of years ago. To determine the history of the different people who may have lived at the site, which is the best method to classify the recovered items?
A. by the type of item
B. by the size of the item
C. by the person who located the item
D. by the soil layer where the item was found
examples.target: D. by the soil layer where the item was found

examples.input:
It is hypothesized that in the next 200 years, the lowest land areas on Earth could be submerged beneath rising oceans. Which climate change would most likely cause this to occur?
A. global warming
B. decreased winds
C. the start of an ice age
D. increased desertification

Miriam notices when she goes to the beach that sometimes the water rises as high as the pier. At other times of the day, the water barely covers the pillars under the pier. These differences in water level are primarily due to the gravitational influence of which of the following?
A. the Sun
B. the Moon
C. asteroids
D. comets

Copper (Cu) reacts with oxygen (O) to form copper oxide (CuO). The properties of CuO are most likely
A. different from copper or oxygen.
B. similar to both copper and oxygen.
C. similar only to copper.
D. similar only to oxygen.
examples.target: A. different from copper or oxygen.

examples.input:
Carbon dioxide produced by cells is removed from the body primarily by which body system?
A. digestive
B. excretory
C. immune
D. respiratory

The ocean minimum zone, or OMZ, is an area from 200 to 600 meters below the ocean's surface. The OMZ is dark and cold, with oxygen concentrations less than 10% of concentrations in surface water. Oxygen concentrations are so low because of bacterial activity that breaks down organic material falling from surface waters. Given the conditions in the OMZ, which of these dissolved gases would you expect to find in large concentrations in this zone?
A. argon
B. nitrogen
C. carbon dioxide
D. carbon monoxide

Two students went fishing one morning and caught 20 fish. The afternoon before, they caught 5 fish. Because of their morning success, they claimed that morning was the best time to fish. Which of these would most likely disprove their claim?
A. catching more than 20 fish in the same location
B. catching more than 20 fish in another location
C. catching more than 20 fish the next afternoon
D. catching more than 20 fish the next morning
examples.target: C. catching more than 20 fish the next afternoon

examples.input:
Which question can be answered by scientific experimentation and observation?
A. Are dogs better pets than cats?
B. How many stars are in the universe?
C. In what type of light will a plant grow best?
D. How many organisms have lived on Earth?
examples.target: C. In what type of light will a plant grow best?

examples.input:
During cellular respiration glucose molecules undergo a series of reactions. This process results in the formation of up to 38 molecules of high-energy ATP per each molecule of glucose. Which is the source of the energy stored in these ATP molecules?
A. kinetic energy generated by the chemical reactions
B. chemical energy originally stored in the glucose molecule
C. electric current created during the destruction of electrons in the glucose
D. potential energy from the difference in the concentration gradients of the cell
examples.target: B. chemical energy originally stored in the glucose molecule

examples.input:
Lea is investigating how phosphates affect oxygen levels in pond water. For part of the investigation, she uses pond water that contains no phosphates. The pond water without phosphates would be what part of the investigation?
A. conclusion
B. hypothesis
C. control group
D. experimental group

Which tool should a student use to examine spots on a frog?
A. thermometer
B. hand lens
C. graduated cylinder
D. magnet

A group of scientists is studying the effect of cell phone signals on honeybees. Before starting the investigation, the scientists stated that the bees exposed to cell phone signals will have difficulty finding their way back to the hive. Which term best describes the statement made by the group of scientists?
A. control
B. data
C. hypothesis
D. variable

Which system is most responsible for transporting blood throughout the body?
A. skeletal system
B. excretory system
C. digestive system
D. circulatory system

Five hundred flies of one species were sprayed with a new insecticide. Twenty-four hours later, nearly all the flies were dead. However, a few survived. Which principle best explains why some flies survived?
A. Animals adapt to new environments.
B. New species develop from survivors.
C. There is variation among individuals within a species.
D. Insecticides may cause genetic mutations.
examples.target: C. There is variation among individuals within a species.

examples.input:
A student investigated the effect of the color of light on the growth of plants. Red, yellow, and green lights were used in the experiment. If another student were to conduct the same experiment, which would be the most important procedure to follow to yield the same results?
A. to do the investigation at the same time of year
B. to use the same chart for recording growth
C. to do the investigation in the same room
D. to use the same colors of lights
examples.target: D. to use the same colors of lights

examples.input:
A large mammal lives in a cold, snowy environment. Which adaptation would best help the mammal survive in low temperatures?
A. thick fur
B. sharp claws
C. large ears
D. strong muscles

The temperatures in space vary from extremely cold to extremely hot. Earth's surface temperature is relatively stable. Which of these is most responsible for Earth's surface temperatures?
A. solar radiation reflected from the Moon
B. many volcanic eruptions near the Ring of Fire
C. the greenhouse effect in the atmosphere
D. plankton distribution in shallow ocean waters
examples.target: C. the greenhouse effect in the atmosphere

examples.input:
Which of the following correctly lists the organizational hierarchy of organisms from simplest to most complex?
A. cells, organs, tissues, organ systems, organisms
B. cells, tissues, organs, organ systems, organisms
C. tissues, cells, organs, organ systems, organisms
D. tissues, organs, cells, organ systems, organisms
examples.target: B. cells, tissues, organs, organ systems, organisms

examples.input:
The carrion flower smells like rotting meat. What kind of pollinator is most likely attracted to the carrion flower?
A. moth
B. butterfly
C. wasp
D. fly

Which of the following best explains why the pressure inside a high-flying airplane must be controlled?
A. At high altitudes there is greater atmospheric pressure than on the surface of the Earth.
B. At high altitudes there is lower atmospheric pressure than on the surface of the Earth.
C. If the cabin is not pressurized, ozone and other upper atmospheric gases will enter the airplane.
D. If the cabin is not pressurized, carbon dioxide will escape from the airplane.
examples.target: B. At high altitudes there is lower atmospheric pressure than on the surface of the Earth.

examples.input:
Hurricanes are large, powerful storms that form as they travel over warm ocean waters. What do oceans add to make hurricanes so strong?
A. salt and water
B. wind and tides
C. heat and moisture
D. waves and flooding

Abnormal cell division may result in
1. disease prevention
2. tissue repair
3. metamorphosis
4. cancer

What is the main reason humans need nitrogen to survive?
A. Nitrogen is used in respiration to generate energy.
B. Nitrogen is used in making the proteins in the body.
C. Nitrogen is used to help the body eliminate wastes.
D. Nitrogen is used by nerve cells to conduct impulses.
examples.target: B. Nitrogen is used in making the proteins in the body.

examples.input:
The phases of the Moon are daily changes in the appearance of the Moon. One reason Moon phases occur is because the Moon reflects sunlight. Which is another reason that the phases of the Moon occur?
A. Earth is tilted on the axis.
B. The Moon rises and sets.
C. The Moon orbits Earth.
D. Earth orbits the Sun.

Some campers are sitting around a campfire outside their tent. Which product of the fire is in the form of electromagnetic waves?
A. light
B. smoke
C. sound
D. water vapor

Jon had a flat tire on his car. He used a hydraulic jack to lift the car up so that he could change the tire. If Jon knows the amount of force used to lift the car 0.25 meter off of the ground, what is he able to calculate?
A. momentum
B. power
C. pressure
D. work

Which organ is made mostly of muscle?
A. heart
B. lung
C. ear
D. brain

Which is considered a property of soil?
A. streak
B. fracture
C. texture
D. luster

Which of these had the greatest impact on the current shape of Nevada's basin and range landscape?
A. tidal forces
B. wind erosion
C. plate tectonics
D. global warming

Which of the following is the primary way that evergreen trees planted on the north and west sides of residences in Massachusetts help reduce winter heating costs?
A. They insulate against cold air.
B. They optimize solar heating.
C. They reduce radiant cooling.
D. They act as a windbreak.
examples.target: D. They act as a windbreak.

examples.input:
Air is composed of nitrogen, oxygen, and other gases. Based on that information, air can be described as
A. a compound.
B. an element.
C. a mixture.
D. a molecule.

Which action should be taken in order to identify the streak of a mineral during an investigation?
A. Weigh the mineral
B. Dip the mineral in acid
C. Heat the mineral until it melts
D. Drag an edge of the mineral across a tile
examples.target: D. Drag an edge of the mineral across a tile

examples.input:
In Type 1 diabetes, the immune system attacks the pancreatic cells that produce insulin. Without insulin, people that have Type 1 diabetes are unable to regulate blood glucose levels. What two symptoms are most likely associated with Type 1 diabetes?
A. extreme thirst and weight loss
B. intense aches and spasms
C. severe loss of hearing and vision
D. excessive loss of coordination and memory
examples.target: A. extreme thirst and weight loss

examples.input:
When the cardboard cone of a radio speaker vibrates, it produces a sound in the air around it. The cone produces this sound by transferring which of the following to the air around it?
A. heat
B. current
C. wave motion
D. magnetic force

During a demonstration, a teacher pours CO_{2} gas over a candle, putting out the flame. Which physical property allows the teacher to pour the CO_{2} gas?
A. The gas is more dense than the air.
B. The gas is more visible than the air.
C. The gas smells different from the air.
D. The gas evaporates faster than the air.
examples.target: A. The gas is more dense than the air.

examples.input:
Atoms of the same element can have different atomic masses because they can have different numbers of
A. neutrons.
B. protons.
C. electrons.
D. neutrinos.

Which would be the best conductor of electricity?
A. air
B. cork
C. water
D. silver

Part of a scientific method involves collecting data in order to
A. change a theory.
B. test a hypothesis.
C. write a procedure.
D. make an observation.

Gravity is a measurable force of attraction which acts upon objects. Which characteristic determines the gravity of an object?
A. friction
B. mass
C. tension
D. weight

Which is NOT an example of a chemical change?
A. Melting ice
B. corroding silver
C. Burning match
D. Rotting vegetation

Seasons in Alaska are primarily caused by which factor as Earth revolves around the Sun?
A. the tilt of Earth on its axis
B. the rate of rotation of Earth
C. the effects of solar flare activity
D. the relative distance between Earth and the Sun
examples.target: A. the tilt of Earth on its axis

examples.input:
A student needs to measure out a precise amount of liquid. What is the best tool for the student to use?
A. test tube
B. meter stick
C. balance scale
D. graduated cylinder

An octopus squirts black ink around itself to hide from predators. This adaptation is an example of
A. creating shelter
B. recycling nutrients
C. a transfer of energy
D. a defense mechanism

Earthquakes are vibrations of Earth's crust. What device is used to measure the size of an earthquake?
A. barometer
B. Doppler radar
C. depth scale
D. seismograph

A girl found the skull of an animal. She did not know what the animal was but she was sure that it preyed on other animals for its food. What clue led to this conclusion?
A. The eye sockets faced sideways.
B. The skull was much longer than it was wide.
C. There was a projecting ridge along the top of the skull.
D. Four of the teeth were long and pointed.
E. The jaws could move sideways as well as up and down.
examples.target: D. Four of the teeth were long and pointed.

examples.input:
Which one of these animals does NOT lay eggs?
A. chickens
B. dogs
C. frogs
D. turtles

Which characteristic does a euglena share with an amoeba?
A. They reproduce by mitosis.
B. They eat by phagocytosis.
C. They respond to light stimuli.
D. They move by changing shape.

Which of the following is most likely to disrupt the natural balance in an ecosystem?
A. introduction of a non-native species
B. reduced daylight hours during winter
C. preventing the cutting of trees in forests
D. riverbank erosion resulting from springtime flooding
examples.target: A. introduction of a non-native species

examples.input:
Which of these correctly lists Earth's layers in order from the center to the surface?
A. outer core, inner core, asthenosphere, lithosphere
B. asthenosphere, lithosphere, outer core, inner core
C. inner core, asthenosphere, lithosphere, outer core
D. inner core, outer core, asthenosphere, lithosphere
examples.target: D. inner core, outer core, asthenosphere, lithosphere

examples.input:
The element nitrogen can be found in simple, nonliving substances, such as air, and in complex molecules in living organisms, such as DNA. Which statement explains why nitrogen can exist in many compounds?
A. Nitrogen atoms are different sizes.
B. Nitrogen atoms are different ages.
C. Nitrogen atoms can bond to different atoms.
D. Nitrogen atoms have different amounts of energy.
examples.target: C. Nitrogen atoms can bond to different atoms.

examples.input:
An enzyme in the Golgi apparatus catalyzes the addition of phosphates to which class of molecule?
A. lipid
B. carbohydrate
C. nucleic acid
D. protein

Which is an example of water condensing? 1.
A. puddle disappearing on a hot summer afternoon
B. Sweat forming on your forehead after you do a lot of exercise
C. Ice cubes melting when you put them out in the sun
D. Dew forming on plants during a cold night
examples.target: D. Dew forming on plants during a cold night

examples.input:
A delta at the mouth of a river is the direct result of
A. runoff from sewage.
B. deposition of sediment.
C. an ancient glacier that passed through.
D. an underground river flowing to the ocean.

examples.input:
Many scientists think that when birds migrate to the same location each year, they find this location by using Earth's
A. jet stream.
B. weather patterns.
C. magnetic patterns.
D. electrical discharges.

Which form of energy do plants need to capture in order to perform photosynthesis?

B. solar
C. chemical
D. electrical

D. gradual ecosystem succession

Sofia put a bat house in a tree in her yard. The bats ate mosquitos in Sofia's yard at night and roosted in the house during the day. Droppings from the bat house nourished the tree. What kind of relationship exists between Sofia, the bats, and the tree?
A. The relationship is competitive.
B. The relationship is cooperative.
C. The relationship is parasitic.
D. The relationship is predatory.

Which of the following is the most basic need for a plant?

B. heat
C. water
D. sand

A scientific article about the universe will most likely describe the universe as

examples.input:

B. balance

The instructions below outline the procedure for a demonstration. Materials: four 100 g metal blocks, each of a different metal four polystyrene foam cups, each containing 150 g of 10°C water Procedure: 1. Place the four cups of water next to each other on the lab bench. 2. Heat each block to a temperature of 60°C. 3. Place each heated block in a separate cup of 10°C water. 4. Measure the temperature change in each cup of water after 100 s. At the end of the demonstration, which block raised the temperature of the 10°C water the greatest amount?

B. the block with the lowest surface area

examples.target: C. the block with the greatest specific heat

examples.input:
On the Galapagos Islands, an iguana that lives in the water is most likely able to survive without competition from an iguana that lives on land because it

B. has a larger body.

D. has a different food source.
examples.target: D. has a different food source.

examples.input:

B. Electricity
C. Sunlight
D. Wind

B. mass
C. weight
D. volume

A dark colored wall becomes warm when the Sun is shining on it. After the Sun sets, a person standing a meter away can feel warmth from the wall. How does heat transfer from the wall to the person?

B. conduction
C. convection
D. insulation

During exercise, the cardiovascular system works together with the respiratory system to

D. filter out waste products.

How does flipping a switch turn on a light?

examples.target: D. It completes an electrical circuit.

examples.input:

D. support the stems and branches.
examples.target: C. protect the plant from harm.

examples.input:
Which of the following is best classified as a nonrenewable resource?

B. Aluminum
C. Sunlight
D. Oxygen

C. Ocean trenches
D. Abyssal plains

Which human body system forms a barrier between internal body structures and the external environment?

B. digestive
C. circulatory
D. integumentary

Decaying plants and animals are important to an ecosystem because they

B. reduce soil erosion.

examples.input:

examples.target: B. The breath mint was more soluble than the toothpaste.

examples.input:
Which is an inherited characteristic on a horse?

A. metals
B. nonmetals
C. elements
D. compounds

Sound waves travel the fastest through dense materials. Through which of these would sound waves travel the SLOWEST?

B. glass
C. metal
D. water

A student dissolves a spoonful of sugar in a glass of water and makes a
A. solute.

D. suspension.

Many scientists are convinced that an increase of certain gases in the atmosphere is affecting global temperatures. What makes this hypothesis difficult to prove?

D. Many human activities produce these gases.
examples.target: C. Many variables affect global temperatures.

examples.input:

D. organelle

B. quartz
C. gypsum
D. sulfur

A student rubs her hands together on a cold winter day. The heat that warms her hands is produced by

B. gravity
C. light
D. magnetism

A. nest building
B. hunting
C. migrating
D. hibernating

Students visit an aquarium and watch how an octopus behaves in its tank. Which behavior did the octopus most likely learn from its aquarium environment?

Cellulose is composed of many sugar molecules bonded together into long chains. Each sugar molecule contains carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen atoms. When cotton fabric is washed, wrinkles often form. The clothing industry uses chemicals to manufacture some cotton fabrics that are wrinkle-free. Dyes are also added to color the cellulose fibers in cotton. A feature that is common to both cellulose and sugar is that both are

B. elements
C. compounds

examples.input:

About how long does it take for Earth to make one revolution around the Sun?

examples.input:

examples.input:

examples.input:

B. round ball

D. wooden cube

When zinc and copper are melted together, brass is formed. Brass is an example of
A. a solute.
B. an element.
C. a mineral.
D. a mixture.

Choose the investigation that would best answer the question: Does the length of a string change how fast a pendulum swings?

examples.input:

B. binary fission

D. fertilization

Some astronauts may spend several months in space orbiting Earth. Where do these astronauts most likely stay while in space?

B. in a space shuttle
C. on a space probe
D. in a lunar module

Which is a possible consequence of global warming?

B. a decrease in temperature, causing earlier frosts

D. a decrease in temperature, causing shorter growing seasons
examples.target: C. an increase in the number of heat waves, causing droughts

examples.input:
A brown bear eats a variety of foods including berries, insects, and small animals. Which best describes a brown bear?
A. producer
B. herbivore
C. carnivore
D. omnivore

In which part of a plant cell does photosynthesis occur?
1. nucleus
2. chloroplast
3. cell membrane
4. cell wall

Which alternative energy resource adds carbon dioxide to the atmosphere?

B. biofuel energy
C. wind energy
D. geothermal energy

Energy from the Sun changes a liquid to a gas by the process of
A. condensation.
B. evaporation.
C. freezing.
D. melting.

Which of the following is a result of the tilt of Earth's axis?

B. hours in a day
C. heights of tides
D. moon phases

Chloroplasts absorb light energy. The function of the chloroplast is to
A. synthesize sugars.
B. synthesize proteins.
C. transform sugar into cellular energy.
D. transform proteins into useful nutrients.

When water changes from a liquid to a gas and then the steam condenses back to the liquid form, these types of changes are
A. physical.
B. chemical.
C. electrical.
D. mechanical.

What direction is the movement of the energy in a food web?
A. consumer to producer
B. producer to consumer

D. decomposer to consumer

When the velocity of an ocean wave decreases as it approaches a shore, what happens to the wave?
A. Its height increases.
B. Its height decreases.
C. Its length shortens.
D. It crests.

Which is a force that keeps Earth in orbit around the Sun?
A. friction
B. gravity
C. radiation
D. magnetism

Substances enter any plant or animal cell by passing through which of the following structures?
A. nucleus
B. cell membrane
C. vacuole
D. chloroplast

Many years ago, purple dye was made from some sea animals. Then, in 1856, William Perkins tried to make a new medicine. Instead, he found a way to make purple dye from coal. What is a positive effect of his discovery?

examples.target: C. Sea animals are not needed to make purple dye.

examples.input:
When magnesium (Mg) metal is burned in the presence of oxygen (O?), magnesium oxide (MgO) is produced. The properties of magnesium oxide are different than the individual properties of magnesium and oxygen because magnesium oxide is
A. a solution.
B. a mixture.
C. a compound.
D. an element.

Fossils of sea animals were found in a cave in Arkansas. What does this mean about that area of Arkansas in the past?
A. It was once underwater.
B. It was once much warmer.
C. It has become a rockier place.
D. It has changed little from then.

Which instrument would be best for measuring the volume of a pebble?
A. metric ruler
B. stopwatch
C. triple beam balance
D. graduated cylinder

Which of these is a waste product of plant cells?
A. minerals
B. oxygen
C. heat
D. water

It can take millions of years for fossil fuels to form. These fossil fuels form underground from decaying plants and animals. Which term best describes a fossil fuel?
A. a source of solar power
B. a source of electrical power
C. a source of renewable energy
D. a source of nonrenewable energy
examples.target: D. a source of nonrenewable energy

examples.input:
Earth's hydrosphere is best described as the
1. relatively thin layer of rock found above Earth's mantle
2. relatively thin layer of water covering most of Earth's crust

4. very dense rock located in Earth's inner core
examples.target: 2. relatively thin layer of water covering most of Earth's crust

examples.input:
When riding a roller coaster, an electric motor pulls the roller coaster to the top of the first hill. What force pulls the roller coaster down the hill?
A. friction
B. speed
C. gravity
D. mass

Which of these organisms is classified as a decomposer?
A. hawk
B. mushroom
C. mouse
D. grass

A cold-blooded vertebrate with smooth skin belongs to what class of animals?
A. reptile
B. fish
C. amphibian
D. mammal

Which of these best describes a tornado?
A. A winter storm that produces frozen precipitation
B. A rotating funnel-shaped cloud with strong winds and thunderstorms
C. A severe weather condition with low temperatures and blowing snow
D. A storm that forms over warm ocean water and has extremely strong winds
examples.target: B. A rotating funnel-shaped cloud with strong winds and thunderstorms

examples.input:
Plants use carbon dioxide from the atmosphere during the process of
A. respiration.
B. fertilization.
C. evaporation.
D. photosynthesis.

A reverse fault occurs when one side of a fault plane is driven up over the other side. Reverse faults can cause which of these landforms?
A. deltas
B. mountains
C. dunes
D. islands

A student is collecting water samples. The student needs a container that holds water, will not break easily, and can be used many times. Which of the following containers will best meet the student's needs?
A. a glass jar
B. a paper cup
C. a wooden box
D. a plastic bottle

What condition is most likely to spread an illness between people?
A. a virus suspended in the air
B. an accident on a playground
C. a genetic mutation in somatic cells
D. an occurrence of acid rain
examples.target: A. a virus suspended in the air

examples.input:
When scientists proposed the Theory of Continental Drift, there were many skeptics. Which discovery confirmed that the continents move on plates?
A. deep-sea currents
B. earthquake formation
C. spreading of the sea floor
D. sedimentary rocks
examples.target: C. spreading of the sea floor

examples.input:
Which two things are produced when a plant breaks down sugar to release energy?
A. carbon dioxide and water
B. oxygen and carbon dioxide
C. carbon dioxide and food
D. oxygen and food

A scientist wants to track contaminant movement in the Gulf Stream. The Gulf Stream is a warm water current in the North Atlantic Ocean and is part of the North Atlantic gyre. The gyre is influenced by the Coriolis effect. To follow the contaminant after it exits the Gulf Stream, the scientist needs to know characteristics of the North Atlantic gyre. Which of these best describes a movement of the North Atlantic gyre the scientist needs to know?
A. linear movement due west
B. linear movement due south
C. clockwise movement
D. counterclockwise movement

The growing human population has many practices that adversely impact the environment. Acid rain is one example of environmental damage that is related to human activities. Which human activity is most likely the largest contributor to acid rain?
A. burning fossil fuels in power plants
B. using pesticides on agricultural crops
C. dumping waste matter into ocean waters
D. clearing native forests for industrialization
examples.target: A. burning fossil fuels in power plants

examples.input:
What happens to the water vapor in an air mass as it ascends?
A. It freezes.
B. It condenses.
C. It vaporizes.
D. It polarizes.

Which two terms are used to describe weather?

B. gravity and amount of rain
C. groundwater and cloud cover
D. air temperature and wind speed
examples.target: D. air temperature and wind speed

examples.input:
In what unit of time does Earth orbit the Sun?
A. day
B. month
C. year
D. century

While conducting an experiment on gravity, what will be needed to ensure the safety of students?
A. quiet zones
B. drop zones
C. heavy objects
D. frictionless surfaces

All of the populations of species in an area make up a
A. region
B. niche
C. family
D. community

Cell division is necessary for an organism to
A. obtain nutrients.
B. grow and reproduce.
C. make proteins.
D. conserve matter and energy.

A large plant population may impose selective pressure on a smaller, isolated group of plants, resulting in a change in allele distribution. Which mechanism is responsible for this change in the allele distribution?
A. mutation
B. hybridization
C. genetic drift
D. trait acquisition

Two samples of gold must have the same
A. mass.
B. volume.
C. length.
D. density.

A student organizes a list of the distances that five students ran in 10 minutes. Another way to best organize this data is by using a
A. pie graph.
B. bar graph.
C. line graph.
D. pictograph.

What is the dependent variable in this experiment?
A. type of soil used
B. amount of water used
C. length of sunlight exposure
D. growth of the bean plants
examples.target: D. growth of the bean plants

examples.input:
Electricity is produced in a hydroelectric plant when moving water turns a turbine. Which describes this energy transformation from the turning turbine to electricity?
A. kinetic energy into electric energy
B. nuclear energy into electric energy
C. thermal energy into electric energy
D. chemical energy into electric energy
examples.target: A. kinetic energy into electric energy

examples.input:
When a star explodes, an intensely bright object is formed. What is the name of this object?
A. nova
B. red giant
C. supernova
D. white dwarf

The Earth's equator receives more direct sunlight than the regions to its north and south. This distribution of sunlight accounts directly for which phenomenon?

C. The rotation of storm systems.
D. The formation of calm "eyes" in the centers of cyclones.
examples.target: B. The movement of rising air currents away from the equator.

examples.input:
The class puts the planters by the window so that the plants can get more sunlight. How do the tomato plants use sunlight?
A. to make sugar in the leaves
B. to use starch from the stems
C. to move water to the flowers
D. to get nutrients through the roots
examples.target: A. to make sugar in the leaves

examples.input:

A. an increase in biodiversity
B. soil erosion along with water pollution
C. the growth of plants in newly cleared areas
D. animals relocating to different habitats
examples.target: B. soil erosion along with water pollution

examples.input:
Gravity is responsible for the ___.
A. orbits of the planets around the Sun
B. rotation of a planet on its axis
C. tilt of Earth's axis
D. phases of the Moon
examples.target: A. orbits of the planets around the Sun

examples.input:
Some runners ate pasta before a race. The pasta was broken down into simple sugars and was absorbed by the blood stream. What body system was responsible for breaking down the pasta into small nutrients for use in the cells of the runners?
A. the nervous system
B. the digestive system
C. the excretory system
D. the endocrine system

Which crustal feature forms when two continental plates collide?
A. trenches
B. rift zones
C. tidal zones
D. mountain ranges

At which location does the movement of tectonic plates form isolated volcanic islands, such as Hawaii?
A. transform boundary
B. divergent boundary
C. subduction zone
D. hot spot

Which current property of our solar system is mainly due to solar emissions occurring soon after the initiation of fusion in the Sun's core?

examples.target: D. distribution of elements among the planets

examples.input:
Water puddles on a sidewalk evaporate when the Sun heats the water. Which of these best describes what is happening as the water evaporates?

examples.target: C. Water becomes a gas as it absorbs energy from the Sun.

examples.input:

examples.target: D. The schoolyard gets little rain during the year.

examples.input:

D. publish the findings in local newspapers
examples.target: C. publish the findings in scientific journals

examples.input:

People often wear sunglasses in polar regions because most of the sunlight that strikes a snow-covered surface is

2. nitrogen

D. water

C. MoCl?

B. gene sequencing

B. refracted.
C. scattered.
D. reflected.

The central nervous system consists of two parts: the brain and the
A. senses.
B. organs.
C. muscles.
D. spinal cord.

B. metals
C. sediment

B. taiga

B. decomposers

B. quartz
C. granite
D. sandstone

Two objects are at rest and are 1.0 meter apart. To reduce the gravitational pull between the two objects, they should be

B. placed side by side.

D. moved 1.5 meters apart.

A. iron
B. silicon
C. calcium
D. magnesium

Which particles make up the mass of an atom?
A. protons and neutrons
B. protons and electrons
C. neutrons and molecules
D. electrons and molecules

Auroras occur where Earth's magnetosphere traps high-energy particles in which region of the atmosphere?
A. troposphere
B. stratosphere

An experiment was performed at sea-level. 400 mL of water was put in 4 different-shaped containers and placed on hot plates with 4 different temperature settings as shown below. A. the shape of the water

examples.target: C. the boiling point of water

examples.input:
In plants, what is responsible for passing traits from one generation to the next?

B. photosynthesis

Which safety measure should a student take when handling a microscope?

examples.target: C. carry the microscope with two hands at all times

examples.input:
Which statement best describes the size of the Sun?
A. The Sun is medium-sized compared to other stars.
B. The Sun is the largest and brightest star in the universe.

D. Most of the stars in the universe are smaller than the Sun.
examples.target: A. The Sun is medium-sized compared to other stars.

examples.input:
A wetland was drained to build a mall. Two years later, there were no more toads in that area. Why did the toads disappear?
A. The toads were destroyed by the construction equipment.
B. The toads died because toads cannot breathe out of water.
C. The toads were frightened and went into the woods.
D. The toads got their food from the wetland ecosystem.
examples.target: D. The toads got their food from the wetland ecosystem.

examples.input:
Technological advances are allowing scientists to develop methods for replacing abnormal human genes with healthy copies of the same genes. Which is the most likely use for this gene therapy?
A. killing viruses
B. healing wounds
C. treatment of airborne infections

Which statement about plant and animal cells is true?
A. Both have a cell wall to give them support.
B. Both have a large vacuole to store water.

examples.target: C. Both use mitochondria to produce energy.

examples.input:
Finding fossils of warm-weather plants in the rock layers of a cold northern island suggests that

examples.target: C. the climate of the island used to be warmer.

examples.input:
The hereditary material in corn plants can be altered by scientists so the plants produce more corn. Which term identifies this process?

2. ecological succession

What is the main function of red blood cells?

B. To carry oxygen to all parts of the body

examples.target: B. To carry oxygen to all parts of the body

examples.input:
Earthquakes and volcanic eruptions occur both on land and in water. Earthquakes and volcanic eruptions most often occur
A. near plate boundaries
B. on large pieces of land
C. in large bodies of water
D. in regions near the equator

An earthworm has a length of 12.8 centimeters. What is the length, in millimeters, of the earthworm?
A. 0.128 millimeter
B. 1.28 millimeters
C. 128 millimeters
D. 1280 millimeters

Which material has the least resistance to the flow of electricity?
A. rubber
B. aluminum
C. granite
D. wood

Which are replenished more quickly than they are used?
A. energy resources
B. material resources
C. renewable resources
D. nonrenewable resources

What is the first thing a student should do before starting an experiment?
A. read all the directions
B. find a lab partner
C. make notes about observations
D. write a report on the investigation

Which of the following parts of the human body is most complex?
A. heart
B. kidney
C. white blood cell
D. central nervous system

The Wright Brothers' invention has had the greatest impact on
A. transportation.
B. communication.
C. mass production.
D. space exploration.

Which best describes how earthworms improve soil as they eat dead plant material?

examples.input:

Cellulose is composed of many sugar molecules bonded together into long chains. Each sugar molecule contains carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen atoms. When cotton fabric is washed, wrinkles often form. The clothing industry uses chemicals to manufacture some cotton fabrics that are wrinkle-free. Dyes are also added to color the cellulose fibers in cotton. How would a clothing manufacturer separate colors to determine the purity of the dyes?

B. by their boiling points
C. by their freezing points
D. through paper chromatography

What property of water is most important for living organisms?

B. It does not conduct electricity.
C. It is tasteless.
D. It is liquid at most temperatures on Earth.
examples.target: D. It is liquid at most temperatures on Earth.

examples.input:
An astronomer and a marine biologist were having lunch and discussing their current experiments. They discovered that although they investigate different areas of science, they most likely use the same
A. scientific tools used in experiments.
B. publications for conducting research.
C. scientific method to test hypotheses.
D. locations for conducting their experiments.
