examples.target: C. scientific method to test hypotheses.

examples.input:
Fossil fuels are formed
A. in shallow areas over short periods of time.
B. from the remains of organisms.
C. in underground reservoirs that are relatively cool.
D. by high winds and temperatures.
examples.target: B. from the remains of organisms.

examples.input:
Which had the greatest impact on the way humans heat their homes?
A. Newton's theory of gravity
B. Mendel's experiments with pea plants
C. Franklin's experiments with electricity
D. Darwin's research on the Galapagos islands

Use the information below to answer the question. Many people are concerned that the reduction in the number of acres of forested area on Earth will lead to a large reduction in the amount of oxygen in Earth's atmosphere. If this happens, an organism's ability to breathe would be affected. The effect would be similar to moving the organism from
A. sea level to a mountaintop.
B. sea level to a valley below sea level.
C. a mountaintop to sea level.
D. a beach at sea level to a valley at sea level.
examples.target: A. sea level to a mountaintop.

examples.input:
Which of these is an example of a chemical reaction?
A. storing milk by putting it into the freezer
B. milk turning sour when left in a warm place
C. mixing milk into a glass with chocolate powder
D. allowing milk to evaporate, leaving behind powdered milk
examples.target: B. milk turning sour when left in a warm place

examples.input:
Which of these tools is best for recording observations outdoors?
A. a ruler
B. a graph
C. a notebook
D. a calculator

Students are investigating the physical properties of three solid mixtures by placing each solid mixture in liquid water. What physical property are the students testing?
A. solubility
B. conductivity
C. boiling point
D. melting point

What remains in the same location in the sky of the Northern Hemisphere each night?
A. the Sun
B. the Little Dipper
C. the North Star
D. the Moon

Which feature makes up most of the surface of Earth?
A. hot gases
B. dry land
C. craters
D. water

Which of these situations would most likely be a result of climate change?
A. weaker storms, causing less shoreline erosion
B. shorter days, causing longer hibernation periods
C. shrinking glaciers, causing sea levels to rise
D. increased radioactivity, causing damage to cells
examples.target: C. shrinking glaciers, causing sea levels to rise

examples.input:
A student performs an investigation using anti-bacterial hand soap. The student washes only his left hand with anti-bacterial soap, but cultures swabs from both hands. The cultures from both hands were incubated at room temperature for 48 hours before being examined. Which best explains the purpose of using soap on only the left hand?
A. to act as a controlled variable for the investigation
B. to act as the dependent variable for the investigation
C. to provide another testable variable for the investigation
D. to serve as the independent variable for the investigation
examples.target: D. to serve as the independent variable for the investigation

examples.input:
Raquel fed a litter of five kittens an all-meat diet for two weeks and found that they gained an average of 15 ounces. She concluded that eating meat is the best way to help kittens grow. What should Raquel have done to make this a better experiment?
A. tested five kittens on a non-meat diet also
B. weighed the kittens in grams
C. used only one kitten
D. tested dogs as well as cats
examples.target: A. tested five kittens on a non-meat diet also

examples.input:
In the 1600s a scientist named Anton van Leeuwenhoek worked toward improving microscopes and created his own lenses. With his microscopes, Leeuwenhoek discovered bacteria and muscle fibers. Which type of job benefited most from these discoveries?
A. glass making
B. astronomy
C. medicine
D. teaching

One advantage of a hand lens over a microscope is that the hand lens
A. is easier to carry on field investigations.
B. is less likely to be infected by bacteria.
C. makes very tiny objects appear larger.
D. produces a more accurate image.
examples.target: A. is easier to carry on field investigations.

examples.input:
Raising livestock, such as sheep and cattle, results in the production of large amounts of methane gas (CH4). Methane has the same effect in the atmosphere as carbon dioxide (CO2). As more livestock are raised to provide food for humans, what is the most likely effect of the increase in methane?
A. acid rain
B. ozone thinning
C. water pollution
D. global warming

Which is most directly responsible for building up a river delta?
A. erosion
B. leaching
C. subsidence
D. deposition

What explains how day and night occur in different parts of Earth?
A. Earth rotates on its axis.
B. Earth revolves around the Sun.
C. The Sun rotates on its axis.
D. The Sun revolves around the galaxy.
examples.target: A. Earth rotates on its axis.

examples.input:
The human body is made up of different levels of organization. A tissue is a group of cells that work together to perform a specific function. Which would be an example of a tissue in the human body?
A. stomach
B. platelets
C. muscle
D. hair

In the rock cycle, sedimentary rock forms when rock is
A. crystallized into natural glass.
B. exposed to great temperature.
C. melted into liquid magma.
D. broken down by weathering.

Heating and cooling water change the state of matter of water. What happens when a block of ice is heated to 10° Celsius?
A. It melts to form liquid water.
B. It condenses to form liquid water.
C. It freezes to become heavier ice.
D. It evaporates to become a vapor (gas).
examples.target: A. It melts to form liquid water.

examples.input:
Which situation is the best example of an inherited trait?
A. a boy playing with a ball
B. a bird building a nest
C. a horse pulling a wagon
D. a dog sitting on command
examples.target: B. a bird building a nest

examples.input:
Physical features help animals survive. Which statement best describes physical adaptations that occur through natural selection in changing environments?
A. They result in population decline.
B. They are all observable in the fossil record.
C. They occur slowly over long periods of time.
D. They are more likely to be observed in plants.
examples.target: C. They occur slowly over long periods of time.

examples.input:
The amount of which greenhouse gas in the air will increase the most if large forests are cut down to be used for building materials without planting new trees in their place?
1. ozone
2. methane
3. water vapor
4. carbon dioxide

A carpenter rubs sandpaper on a wooden bench to make the bench smoother. The sandpaper will get warm as it is rubbed on the bench. As a result of the friction between the sandpaper and the bench, thermal energy is converted to
A. chemical energy that is stored by the sandpaper.
B. radiant energy that is transferred to the bench.
C. potential energy that is stored by the wood.
D. heat energy that is transferred to the air.
examples.target: D. heat energy that is transferred to the air.

examples.input:
What is the green pigment that allows plants to change the Sun's energy into chemical energy?
A. glucose
B. chlorophyll
C. mitochondria
D. photosynthesis

Which scientist hypothesized that the environment can affect the characteristics of a species?
A. Darwin
B. Einstein
C. Mendel
D. Newton

Which statement describes the reason why an ice cube melts when set out in a warm room?
A. Heat from the room is absorbed by the ice cube.
B. The ice cube molecules move more slowly.
C. One side of the ice cube is colder than the other.
D. Heat from the ice cube moves into the air.
examples.target: A. Heat from the room is absorbed by the ice cube.

examples.input:
Two characteristics of the Nevada climate are low humidity and abundant sunshine. This combination of characteristics most likely results in
A. low altitude fog.
B. rapid evaporation.
C. high elevation snowfall.
D. frequent thunderstorms.

In order to survive, all animals need
A. heat, water, and soil
B. sunlight, soil, and heat
C. sunlight, air, and food
D. food, water, and air

Which best explains why population growth can result in water shortages and rationing in certain areas?
A. Aquifers recharge slowly.
B. Lake water is reserved for recreation.
C. Increasing biomass decreases evaporation rates.
D. Tall buildings impede the development of rain clouds.

Professor Walden studies genetics at a local university. She believes that she has discovered information that contradicts a widely accepted theory. As a scientist and leader in the study of genetics, which action should she take?
A. Announce to the world that her theory is better than the old theory.
B. Call the news media and tell them about her new theory.
C. Challenge the old theory with scientific evidence.
D. Request that the old theory be banned.
examples.target: C. Challenge the old theory with scientific evidence.

examples.input:
Canadian physician Sir William Osler once said, "In Science the credit goes to the man who convinces the world, not to the man to whom the idea first occurred." How does this quote apply to scientific knowledge?
A. Famous scientists have the best ideas.
B. Ideas must be communicated to the public
C. In order to be important, ideas must be believable.
D. The results are less important than the ideas in an experiment.
examples.target: B. Ideas must be communicated to the public

examples.input:
Which event or principle cannot have its validity directly tested by laboratory experiment?
A. the Big Bang Theory
B. the Conservation of Energy
C. the Periodicity of Element Properties
D. the Acceleration of Objects due to Gravity

How do the circulatory system and the respiratory system depend on one another?
A. Oxygen collected by the respiratory system is carried throughout the body by the circulatory system.
B. Solid wastes collected by the circulatory system are carried throughout the body by the respiratory system.
C. Nutrients collected by the respiratory system are carried throughout the body by the circulatory system.
D. Carbon dioxide collected by the circulatory system is carried throughout the body by the respiratory system.
examples.target: A. Oxygen collected by the respiratory system is carried throughout the body by the circulatory system.

examples.input:
Oxygen and iron combine chemically to form rust. Rust is classified as which of the following?
A. an atom
B. a compound
C. an element
D. a mixture

A student made observations of four rock samples. Which of these observations most likely describes a sedimentary rock?
A. Sample 1 has bands of light and dark crystals.
B. Sample 2 has pink, gray, and white crystals grown together.
C. Sample 3 is made up of one huge, pale pink crystal.
D. Sample 4 is made up of layers of sand grains cemented together.
examples.target: D. Sample 4 is made up of layers of sand grains cemented together.

examples.input:
In 1931, Barbara McClintock discovered that genes could change position on a chromosome. In corn plants, if a certain gene was moved next to the gene that controls kernel color, the kernels in an ear of corn were various colors. Which statement best supports McClintock's discovery?
A. Genes control inherited traits in organisms.
B. Corn plants can reproduce in laboratory environments.
C. Chromosomes can move around in the nucleus of a cell.
D. Genes are able to disappear and reappear in later generations.
examples.target: A. Genes control inherited traits in organisms.

examples.input:
Herbivores obtain most of their energy by
1. consuming animals
2. consuming plants
3. producing sugar
4. absorbing sunlight

Which factor has the greatest effect on a community's stores of freshwater?
A. the location of the nearest ocean
B. the average annual rainfall
C. the location of the nearest mountain
D. the average winter temperature

A researcher's plan is to place five fish in separate tanks, give them the same amount of food each day, and keep the temperature the same. One fish will be exposed to artificial light for 24 hours each day, while the others will have light for 22 hours and then no light for 2 hours each day. Which is the control for this experiment?
A. the separate tanks
B. the amount of food
C. the fish deprived of light
D. the fish exposed to light for 24 hours
examples.target: D. the fish exposed to light for 24 hours

examples.input:
Use The Periodic Table of the Elements and the information below to answer the question. Magnesium metal (Mg) is grayish-white in color and reacts actively with water. Fluorine (F2) is a greenish-yellow gas at room temperature and is a member of the halogen family. These two elements react to produce magnesium fluoride (MgF2), a chemical commonly used in making windows and lenses. How does adding heat energy affect magnesium fluoride (MgF2) molecules?
A. The motion of the molecules stops.
B. The motion of the molecules increases.
C. The motion of the molecules decreases.
D. The motion of the molecules is at a constant rate.
examples.target: B. The motion of the molecules increases.

examples.input:
A shift in climate changes a forested area with little annual snowfall to an area with snowfall most of the year. Natural selection would most likely favor a rabbit with which adaptation?
A. dark coat color
B. increased body fat
C. large ears to release body heat
D. more powerful legs for burrowing

When humans move into an area, they sometimes plant grasses, flowers, or trees that are not native to the area. The non-native species sometimes choke out the native species. Which organism would most likely be harmed by a loss of native plants in the area?
A. the fungi that break down dead plants
B. the beetles that eat a variety of grass roots
C. the mosquitoes that hide under plant leaves
D. the caterpillars that eat only one type of plant
examples.target: D. the caterpillars that eat only one type of plant

examples.input:
What is a way of improving air quality?
A. driving large cars
B. building more factories
C. burning wood in the fireplace
D. using solar energy to produce electricity
examples.target: D. using solar energy to produce electricity

examples.input:
Which tool should be used to measure the stem length of a plant?
A. a balance
B. a metric ruler
C. a graduated cylinder
D. a thermometer

In which of these organs does most absorption of nutrients take place?
A. liver
B. stomach
C. small intestine
D. large intestine

Proper use and care of a microscope includes
A. carrying it with both hands.
B. reflecting sunlight to the stage.
C. removing the objectives after you are done.
D. adjusting the coarse focus under high power.
examples.target: A. carrying it with both hands.

examples.input:
All matter is made up of
1. cells
2. atoms
3. molecules
4. compounds

Which physical change would most likely help an animal survive during the winter?
A. tail gets longer
B. fur gets thicker
C. feathers are shed
D. whiskers get shorter

Which of these steps in the rock cycle occurs ONLY in the formation of metamorphic rock?
A. erosion
B. compaction
C. cementation
D. recrystallization

A tulip growing in a pot is placed at the center of a table. Which of these nearby objects will the tulip grow toward?
A. a sunny window
B. an electric heater
C. a large bowl of water
D. a fan blowing gently

Common soaps are often basic. Which of these is a property of a chemical base?
A. sour taste
B. pH equal to 6
C. turns litmus paper blue
D. forms bubbles with limestone

As temperatures increase, which process is responsible for increasing the amount of water vapor in the atmosphere?
A. ionization
B. evaporation
C. respiration
D. condensation

Why do some animals hibernate in the winter?
A. to find food for their young
B. to adapt to environmental changes
C. to attract a mate
D. to avoid predators
examples.target: B. to adapt to environmental changes

examples.input:
Which wind-water interaction is responsible for cycling nutrient-rich waters from the ocean floor to the sea surface?
A. upwelling
B. storm surge
C. downwelling
D. surface currents

If a cell is exposed to a chemical that inhibits the production of spindle fibers as the cell is preparing for mitosis, what would most likely happen?
A. The cell would continue with mitotic division.
B. The cell would undergo meiotic division.
C. The cell would break open.
D. The cell would not divide.
examples.target: D. The cell would not divide.

examples.input:
Norma's flashlight was not working. She replaced the old batteries with new ones, and the flashlight turned on. Why did the flashlight work after she replaced the batteries?
A. because the batteries conduct the electricity
B. because the batteries supply the energy
C. because the batteries produce light
D. because the batteries produce heat
examples.target: B. because the batteries supply the energy

examples.input:
The sun provides heat and light to Earth. The sun is best described as
A. a planet close to Earth
B. the closest star to Earth
C. a planet that reflects light
D. the center of the universe
examples.target: B. the closest star to Earth

examples.input:
A large piece of ice is placed on the sidewalk on a warm day. What will happen to the ice?
A. It will melt to form liquid water.
B. It will melt to form water vapor.
C. It will freeze to form liquid water.
D. It will not change at all.
examples.target: A. It will melt to form liquid water.

examples.input:
Ducks live near ponds and lakes. The shape of a duck's foot helps it swim and walk on muddy ground. Which factor is most important in determining the shape of a baby duck's foot?
A. the shape of the parent ducks' feet
B. the temperature of the pond water
C. the amount of mud in the bottom of the pond
D. the amount of rain that fell before the duck was born
examples.target: A. the shape of the parent ducks' feet

examples.input:
The Moon revolves around the Earth because of a non-contact force. What force of Earth keeps the Moon in orbit?
A. electrical force
B. magnetic force
C. centripetal force
D. gravitational force

Which motion causes the pattern of day and night on Earth?
A. Earth rotates on its axis
B. Earth orbits around the sun
C. the moon rotates on its axis
D. the moon orbits around Earth
examples.target: A. Earth rotates on its axis

examples.input:
What causes ocean water to evaporate in the water cycle?
A. energy from the Sun
B. energy from ocean waves
C. energy from Earth's rotation
D. energy from Earth's moon

Some cells, such as human nerve and muscle cells, contain many more mitochondria than do other cells, such as skin cells. Why do some cells have more mitochondria than others?
A. The cells use more energy.
B. The cells store more nutrients.
C. The cells degrade more proteins.
D. The cells divide more frequently.
examples.target: A. The cells use more energy.

examples.input:
A student finds that an unidentified mineral sample can scratch gypsum but is unable to scratch quartz. The student has made an observation about which property of the sample?
A. luster
B. hardness
C. density
D. reactivity

Which process is the best example of weathering?
A. A cloud releases freezing rain.
B. A tree root breaks apart a rock.
C. Dry weather results in a small harvest.
D. Sediments flow into a bay.
examples.target: B. A tree root breaks apart a rock.

examples.input:
What is the major source of energy for food chains?
A. water
B. air
C. sunlight
D. grass

Elias investigates whether soaking beans in water before planting affects how the beans grow. Which beans would most likely be the control group?
A. the beans that were soaked the least amount of time
B. the beans that were not soaked in water
C. the beans that had the greatest mass
D. the beans that grew the tallest
examples.target: B. the beans that were not soaked in water

examples.input:
What type of galaxy most likely can be described as a large, flat disk surrounded by arms of stars and dust?
A. elliptical
B. irregular
C. ring
D. spiral

Which is true of a car that is accelerating along a horizontal roadway?
A. Its kinetic energy is increasing
B. Its kinetic energy is decreasing.
C. Its potential energy is increasing.
D. Its potential energy is decreasing.
examples.target: A. Its kinetic energy is increasing

examples.input:
A hypothesis that is successfully tested many times may become a
A. conclusion.
B. theory.
C. constant.
D. law.

Which of the following do plants need to make their own food?
A. Flowers
B. Bacteria
C. Sunlight
D. Oxygen

What is the result of the rapid shifting in Earth's surface?
A. a tornado
B. an earthquake
C. a volcano
D. an avalanche

Ned learned that light is a source of energy. Which can only result from light energy?
A. an ice cube melting
B. a rainbow forming
C. water evaporating
D. thunder booming

At which location are oceans the deepest?
A. Mid-ocean ridge
B. Abyssal plain
C. Ocean trench
D. Volcanic island

Kendra's mom is purchasing a car, but cannot decide what color to get. Kendra advises her mom that a car with a black exterior will be uncomfortable in the summer. This observation is correct because dark objects, as compared to lighter colored objects,
A. reduce heat transfer.
B. are generally more dense.
C. absorb more of the Sun's energy.
D. reflect sunlight more efficiently.
examples.target: C. absorb more of the Sun's energy.

examples.input:
Heart cells have fibers that slide up and down and cause contractions. Which types of specialized cells can contract?
A. bone cells
B. nerve cells
C. muscle cells
D. white blood cells

What can we learn by studying fossils?
A. how hurricanes formed long ago
B. how the solar system was formed
C. the cause of strong earthquakes
D. how Earth's environments have changed
examples.target: D. how Earth's environments have changed

examples.input:
If a string on a musical instrument like a guitar is made tighter, the sound produced by that string will always be
A. lower pitched.
B. higher pitched.
C. louder.
D. quieter.

Iron oxide, also known as rust, is formed when iron chemically combines with oxygen. Which term best describes iron oxide?
A. element
B. mixture
C. solution
D. compound

Which is a trait that a child can inherit from its parents?
A. eye color
B. a broken leg
C. length of hair
D. language skills

Some dairy farmers want their cows to produce greater amounts of milk than average cows. Which process will help the dairy farmers develop cows with this trait?
A. selective breeding
B. behavioral modification
C. ecological succession
D. geographical isolation

Which tool will best help scientists understand relationships between oceans and climate changes?
A. a computer model
B. a weather balloon
C. a rain gauge
D. radar

A student mixes a spoonful of sand into a beaker of water. Which two methods can be used to separate the sand from the water?
A. filtration and evaporation
B. settling and chromatography
C. chromatography and filtration
D. settling and magnetic attraction

A warm-blooded organism that nurses its young would be called
A. a bird.
B. an insect.
C. a mammal.
D. a reptile.

Elements on the Periodic Table of the Elements are classified into categories such as
1. rocks and minerals
2. molecules and atoms
3. mixtures and compounds
4. metals and nonmetals

In a genetics investigation, students used two red straws to represent male parent DNA. They used two green straws to represent female parent DNA. The offspring in this activity are best represented by
A. either one red straw or one green straw.
B. two green straws.
C. two red straws.
D. one red straw and one green straw.
examples.target: D. one red straw and one green straw.

examples.input:
The process of cellular respiration occurs in
A. both plant and animal cells.
B. plant cells only.
C. animal cells only.
D. neither plant nor animal cells.
examples.target: A. both plant and animal cells.

examples.input:
Ana rolled her wagon down the ramp to reach the playground. There, she and her sister played on the seesaw. Which set of simple machines has Ana used?
A. Lever, pulley, and wedge
B. Pulley, inclined plane, and screw
C. Wedge, wheel and axle, and screw
D. Wheel and axle, inclined plane, and lever
examples.target: D. Wheel and axle, inclined plane, and lever

examples.input:
Which of these features, formed east of the Sierra Nevada Mountain Range, is due to moist air rising along the western slope of the mountain range?
A. desert
B. grassland
C. rain forest
D. temperate forest

Human activity most likely contributes to which of the following changes on Earth?
A. an increase in the length of a day
B. a decrease in the number of volcanic eruptions
C. a decrease in the magnitude of large earthquakes
D. an increase in the amount of atmospheric carbon dioxide
examples.target: D. an increase in the amount of atmospheric carbon dioxide

examples.input:
A student is reading the nutritional information on a box of cereal. It says that a single serving contains 215 calories. Which type of energy is being measured by this unit?
A. kinetic
B. chemical
C. electrical
D. mechanical

Crustal plates that pull apart from one another most likely form
A. volcanic island arcs.
B. strike-slip faults.
C. oceanic trenches.
D. rift zones.

A change in the position of an object as time changes best describes
A. direction.
B. waves.
C. motion.
D. frequency.

What two organ systems are involved in the transfer of oxygen to the cells from outside the body?
A. skeletal and digestive
B. skeletal and respiratory
C. circulatory and digestive
D. circulatory and respiratory

Sodium (Na) and chlorine (Cl) are two reactive and dangerous elements. Chlorine is a halogen gas that can cause respiratory damage and sodium is an alkali metal that reacts violently with water. What happens to the properties of sodium and chlorine when they react to form sodium chloride (NaCl), common table salt?
A. The properties of both sodium and chlorine change.
B. The properties of both sodium and chlorine remain the same.
C. The properties of sodium are different but chlorine remains a dangerous gas.
D. The properties of sodium remain the same but the properties of chlorine change.
examples.target: A. The properties of both sodium and chlorine change.

examples.input:
Which list includes only examples of matter that can take the shape of a container?
A. oil, air, and rock
B. water, air, and milk
C. sand, ice, and wood
D. nail, stick, and paper

Which source of energy is nonrenewable?
A. coal
B. sunlight
C. water
D. wood

Which of the following is most necessary for life to develop on another planet?
A. liquid water
B. rocky surfaces
C. warm soil
D. atmospheric oxygen

Plants that are different from each another may have similar structures. Which structure do all plants have in common?
A. flowers
B. fruit
C. roots
D. trunks

Which organism is a producer?
A. frog
B. mushroom
C. grass
D. lizard

Some machines have been designed to perform complicated tasks which result from a demand for
A. minimizing illness from disease.
B. minimizing the need for manual labor.
C. maximizing the price of consumer goods.
D. maximizing the use of non-renewable resources.
examples.target: B. minimizing the need for manual labor.

examples.input:
Scientists are developing new satellite technology to help predict the weather. How will developing this technology most likely benefit people?
A. It will show people that storms can be prevented.
B. It will show people that science is interesting.
C. It will help warn people about dangerous storms.
D. It will help people drive in the rain.
examples.target: C. It will help warn people about dangerous storms.

examples.input:
Which statement about gravity is written as a law?
A. The reason gravity works is because masses bend time and space.
B. The effect of gravity on plants might be reduced if certain minerals are added to the soil.
C. The force of gravity between two objects depends upon their masses and the distance between them.
D. The experiments being done on gravity today are better than what were done in the past and a full understanding is only a few years away.
examples.target: C. The force of gravity between two objects depends upon their masses and the distance between them.

examples.input:
What does the brain monitor to control the rate of breathing during normal activities?
A. the level of carbon dioxide in the blood
B. the level of carbon dioxide in the cells
C. the level of carbon dioxide in the lungs
D. the level of carbon dioxide in the air
examples.target: A. the level of carbon dioxide in the blood

examples.input:
A researcher is measuring changes in the density of the upper atmosphere over time. Which units should be used for the density measurements?
A. kg/s
B. m^3/s
C. L/m^3
D. kg/m^3

Which function requires the muscular, skeletal, and nervous systems to work together?
A. movement of appendages
B. completion of blood circulation
C. absorption of nutrients
D. regulation of hormones

Michael Faraday showed how electric current in a wire produces
A. molecules
B. chemicals
C. a vibration
D. a magnetic field

Mrs. Moyers teaches her students about different energy sources. Which example comes from a renewable source of energy?
A. water heated by solar panels
B. food cooked over natural gas
C. electricity produced from coal
D. an engine powered by gasoline
examples.target: A. water heated by solar panels

examples.input:
What is at the center of our solar system?
A. a medium planet with an atmosphere.
B. a star composed of carbon and nitrogen.
C. a black hole that was once a star.
D. a star composed of hydrogen and helium.
examples.target: D. a star composed of hydrogen and helium.

examples.input:
Which device directly converts chemical energy into electrical energy?
1. solar-powered calculator
2. wood-burning stove
3. battery-powered flashlight
4. wind-powered sailboat

Some students have gathered a collection of rock samples from the school yard to study. They scraped the rocks against a piece of quartz from the school lab. Which property of minerals are the students investigating?
A. texture
B. hardness
C. color
D. streak

Which organisms eat only plants?
A. producers
B. omnivores
C. herbivores
D. scavengers

Which of the following is a characteristic of the "steady state theory" of the universe?
A. The universe is constantly growing and changing.
B. A great explosion caused the origin of the universe.
C. The nature of the universe has always been the same.
D. Light moving from the center of the universe appears red.
examples.target: C. The nature of the universe has always been the same.

examples.input:
A sunspot appears as a dark spot on the sun that is cooler than the surrounding area. On which region of the sun do sunspots occur?
A. chromosphere
B. core
C. corona
D. photosphere

The Great Miami Aquifer is a large underground water supply that lies under much of southwest Ohio. The water level of the aquifer could be reduced over time by too much
A. rainfall.
B. pollution.
C. irrigation.
D. evaporation.

What kind of energy conversion occurs after a candle is lit?
A. friction to electrical energy
B. light energy to heat energy
C. mass to kinetic energy
D. chemical energy to light energy
examples.target: D. chemical energy to light energy

examples.input:
What is one way the body reacts to cold weather?
A. sneezing
B. swallowing
C. shivering
D. sweating

Running to escape danger is an action that requires the nervous system to coordinate the interaction of which two body systems?
1. digestive and endocrine
2. muscular and skeletal
3. reproductive and excretory
4. circulatory and digestive

What causes day and night on Earth?
A. Earth's rotation on its axis
B. the Sun's revolution around Earth
C. Earth's revolution around the Sun
D. the Sun's rotation on its axis
examples.target: A. Earth's rotation on its axis

examples.input:
Which is the best explanation of why the Moon revolves around Earth?
A. The Moon has a thinner atmosphere than Earth.
B. The Moon is too large to move away from Earth.
C. The Moon is attracted by the gravity of Earth.
D. The Moon has a smaller gravitational force than Earth.
examples.target: C. The Moon is attracted by the gravity of Earth.

examples.input:
Which observation provides evidence of the existence of planets orbiting other stars?
A. periodic dimming of the stars
B. periodic X-ray bursts from the stars
C. rapid location changes of the stars
D. regular spectrum changes from the stars
examples.target: A. periodic dimming of the stars

examples.input:
Mutations that occur in sex cells can be passed from parent to offspring during
A. cloning.
B. budding.
C. binary fission.
D. sexual reproduction.

Which type of ecosystem has the greatest variation in temperature from its top to its bottom?
A. lake
B. pond
C. ocean
D. estuary

What two factors determine the location of an electron around the nucleus of the atom?
A. speed and direction of the electron
B. size of the electron and the neutron
C. direction and strength of the electron
D. energy and the attraction of the nucleus
examples.target: D. energy and the attraction of the nucleus

examples.input:
The removal of waste from Florida's East Bay and Pensacola Bay is intended to speed the bay ecosystem's natural tendency to do which of the following?
A. adapt to a changed landscape
B. undergo ecosystem progression
C. return to its pre-pollution conditions
D. produce organisms that can survive changed conditions
examples.target: C. return to its pre-pollution conditions

examples.input:
Matter is defined as anything that takes up space and has
A. mass
B. texture
C. odor
D. color

Which is the order of the planets from closest to the Sun to farthest from the Sun?
A. Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars
B. Mars, Mercury, Earth, Venus
C. Earth, Venus, Mercury, Mars
D. Venus, Earth, Mars, Mercury

In living things, large and complex molecules are broken down into small and simple molecules. What is this process called?
A. excretion
B. absorption
C. digestion
D. circulation

Meadow voles are small mouse-like animals that eat plants and insects. Their niche in an ecosystem is a
A. omnivore.
B. herbivore.
C. producer.
D. scavenger.

A dietary supplement manufacturer developed a new calcium supplement that appears to increase the bone density in middle-aged women. When tested in a small clinical trial, the supplement was shown to cause a 15% increase in bone density in 8 out of 10 women. Before the supplement is offered to the general public, which step should the manufacturer take next?
A. add a variety of vitamins to the supplement
B. test the supplement on mice in the laboratory
C. develop packaging that is attractive to women
D. test the supplement on a larger sample of women
examples.target: D. test the supplement on a larger sample of women

examples.input:
The European starling entered North America in the late 1800s. It proved very successful and was able to spread throughout the United States by 1955. The survival and rapid reproduction of starlings most likely limited the population size of which organisms within its habitats?
A. its decomposers
B. its competitors
C. its mutualists
D. its predators

Which does 12.0 grams represent?
A. mass
B. volume
C. speed
D. force

Which of the following statements best describes the process of natural selection in a population?
A. All individuals develop traits to match changes to their environment.
B. All individuals learn to adapt to specific changes that occur slowly in their environment.
C. Some individuals respond to their environment by mutating to make themselves more likely to survive.
D. Some individuals have genetic differences that make them more likely to survive and reproduce in their environment.
examples.target: D. Some individuals have genetic differences that make them more likely to survive and reproduce in their environment.

examples.input:
A researcher is working on a family genetics project. She wants to trace a particular trait back through several generations of her ancestors. Which type of display will best help the researcher organize the information?
A. flow chart
B. cycle diagram
C. pedigree chart
D. Punnett square

Joyce put 200 milliliters of water in a beaker, put a thermometer in it, and heated it until it started to boil. She recorded a temperature of 100°C when it started to boil. She repeated the process with 400 milliliters of water. What would be the temperature when this second sample started to boil?
A. twice as high as the first sample's
B. slightly higher than the first sample's
C. half as high as the first sample's
D. the same as the first sample's
examples.target: D. the same as the first sample's

examples.input:
Between 40 and 50 million years ago, the landmass on the Indian plate collided with the landmass on the Eurasian plate. What formed when these landmasses collided?
A. the Grand Canyon
B. the Great Plains
C. the Himalayan Mountains
D. the Mariana Trench

Hawaii is composed mainly of volcanoes with gentle slopes and large surface areas. Which characteristics best describe the lava these volcanoes have released?
A. relatively fluid and low viscosity
B. highly viscous and relatively cool
C. mix of hot gas and rock shards
D. mainly water vapor and large boulders
examples.target: A. relatively fluid and low viscosity

examples.input:
Mrs. Henderson's class has five small covered boxes. One contains perfume; another contains dried onions. There is also a box of pine needles, a box of lemon pieces, and a box with a paper towel wetted with vanilla flavoring. Which should they do to get the best information about what is in each box?
A. Shake the boxes.
B. Smell the boxes.
C. Listen to the boxes.
D. Weigh the boxes.

Which of these best describes the relationship between Earth's layers?
A. The hottest layers are closest to the core.
B. The more liquid layers are closest to the crust.
C. The lightest layers are closest to the core.
D. The more metallic layers are closest to the crust.
examples.target: A. The hottest layers are closest to the core.

examples.input:
A neutral atom is best described as having
A. more protons than neutrons.
B. more electrons than protons.
C. an equal number of protons and neutrons.
D. an equal number of protons and electrons.
examples.target: D. an equal number of protons and electrons.

examples.input:
Which statement best describes a learned characteristic in a dog?
A. A dog scratches at a door to go outside.
B. A dog has floppy ears.
C. A dog pants to cool itself on a hot day.
D. A dog has a dark coat.
examples.target: A. A dog scratches at a door to go outside.

examples.input:
In the Northern Hemisphere, June 21st has more hours of sunlight than any other day. However, June 21st has the fewest hours of sunlight in the Southern Hemisphere. Which best explains why the Northern Hemisphere receives more daylight than the Southern Hemisphere on the same day?
A. Earth rotates on its axis
B. Earth is tilted on its axis
C. The Sun moves closer to the Northern Hemisphere
D. The Sun releases more energy to the Northern Hemisphere
examples.target: B. Earth is tilted on its axis

examples.input:
Which of these shows the correct order needed for a solar eclipse to happen?
A. Sun, Earth, Moon
B. Sun, Moon, Earth
C. Moon, Sun, Earth
D. Moon, Earth, Sun

A greenhouse is an example of a closed system. Which two types of energy are exchanged in this system?
A. radiant energy for nuclear energy
B. radiant energy for thermal energy
C. thermal energy for nuclear energy
D. nuclear energy for chemical energy
examples.target: B. radiant energy for thermal energy

examples.input:
Which of the following has changed over the last 200 years primarily due to human activity?
A. Earth's magnetic field
B. the frequency of earthquakes
C. Earth's tectonic plate activity
D. the composition of the atmosphere
examples.target: D. the composition of the atmosphere

examples.input:
What physical property is characteristic of all of the elements in the group located in the rightmost column of the periodic table?
A. very high melting point
B. gas state at room temperature
C. good conductor of electric current
D. extremely brittle solid at room temperature
examples.target: B. gas state at room temperature

examples.input:
Which difference between land and water contributes most directly to global climate change resulting from tectonic movement?
A. mean material densities
B. magnetic material content
C. heat absorption and retention properties
D. rate of radioactivity-related heat release
examples.target: C. heat absorption and retention properties

examples.input:
How does the Sun most affect the water cycle?
A. The Sun causes the ocean water to evaporate.
B. The Sun creates water droplets in the clouds.
C. The Sun forces water to drain back into the ocean.
D. The Sun makes the clouds produce precipitation.
examples.target: A. The Sun causes the ocean water to evaporate.

examples.input:
Many sports stadiums use grass, but some use fake grass called artificial turf. Artificial turf is made of fibers that look like real grass. In which way is this technology most likely beneficial?
A. It uses less water.
B. It produces more heat.
C. It releases less moisture.
D. It absorbs more carbon dioxide.

The western coast of the United States has been increasing in size for millions of years. Which process has added material to the western coast of the United States?
A. deposition at transform boundaries
B. accretion at convergent boundaries
C. landslides at divergent boundaries
D. meteorite impact at convergent boundaries

Which of the following structures enables fish to remain at a certain depth without expending energy through swimming?
A. swim bladder
B. lateral line
C. dorsal fin
D. gill slits

Before strip mining for coal, the topsoil in the area is removed and stored. After mining operations are completed, the land is leveled and topsoil is replaced. The purpose of replacing topsoil is
A. to prevent wind from weathering and eroding surface coal.
B. to prevent radioactive elements from polluting water sources.
C. to provide an environment for new coal formation.
D. to restore the area to a natural condition.
examples.target: D. to restore the area to a natural condition.

examples.input:
Which event is the best example of competition between species in a pond environment?
1. dragonflies landing on lily pads
2. frogs and toads eating flies
3. lizards and snakes lying in the sun
4. hawks eating mice

What is the most likely effect of a drought on a population of frogs that live in a shallow swamp?
A. only younger frogs will survive
B. the number of predators will increase
C. decrease in frog population as water evaporates
D. increase in frog population as more land is exposed
examples.target: C. decrease in frog population as water evaporates

examples.input:
The following waste materials are buried in a landfill. Which will break down most quickly?
A. steel
B. plastic
C. glass
D. paper

What is the source of genetic information of offspring produced by sexual reproduction?
A. the father only
B. the mother only
C. the mother and the father
D. neither the mother nor the father
examples.target: C. the mother and the father

examples.input:
Why do multicellular organisms need transport systems?
A. Most have cells that are not able to exchange gases with the outside environment.
B. Most have cells that are unable to grow and survive in their environment.
C. Most have cells that need food from sources outside their environment.
D. Most have cells that require more energy to survive than single-celled organisms.
examples.target: A. Most have cells that are not able to exchange gases with the outside environment.

examples.input:
Scientists frequently monitor levels of microorganisms at beaches in the summer time. High temperatures, pollution, runoff, and illegal dumping all affect water quality. What do these scientific efforts illustrate?
A. Pollution can be eliminated through water testing.
B. High temperatures increase runoff from agricultural fields.
C. Water testing identifies origination of illegal dumping.
D. Monitoring water quality is important to public health.
examples.target: D. Monitoring water quality is important to public health.

examples.input:
Machines are often full of moving parts that rub against each other. In machines, a lubricant such as oil is often applied to these moving parts. Why is this oil necessary?
A. to enhance the effectiveness of friction
B. to increase the efficiency of the machine
C. to provide an additional source of energy
D. to produce more thermal energy on the machine
examples.target: B. to increase the efficiency of the machine

examples.input:
The manufacturing process used to permanently put parts together is called
A. cutting.
B. shaping.
C. finishing.
D. assembling.

Solids, liquids, and gases are all different states of which of the following?
A. mass
B. matter
C. weight
D. volume

Animals respond to environmental stimuli obtained through their sensory organs. How does the body convert information from the environment to an internal response?
A. increased cellular temperature
B. selective membrane transport
C. chemical signaling
D. osmotic pressure

Which is a primary energy source used by power plants to generate electricity?
A. coal
B. wood
C. gasoline
D. batteries

Perry studies the ways in which animals are adapted for survival. Which is a behavioral adaptation that helps the organism to survive?
A. the long neck on a giraffe
B. the webbed feet on a duck
C. a bear hibernating in winter
D. a flower attracting a honeybee
examples.target: C. a bear hibernating in winter

examples.input:
A helium-filled balloon is released into the atmosphere. As the balloon rises, which would most likely increase and cause the balloon to burst?
A. the mass of the helium
B. the density of the helium
C. the volume of the helium
D. the temperature of the helium
examples.target: C. the volume of the helium

examples.input:
Which of the following is composed of many cells?
A. virus
B. bacterium
C. paramecium
D. plant

As a result of human activity, many lakes in Florida have increased levels of nutrients that support algal growth. These algae grow very rapidly, then die and decompose. What impact does this overgrowth of algae most likely have on the lake ecosystem?
A. The number of fish species increases.
B. The volume of lake water increases.
C. The buildup of bottom sediments decreases.
D. The amount of dissolved oxygen decreases.
examples.target: D. The amount of dissolved oxygen decreases.

examples.input:
The color of which animal allows it to blend into its environment?
A. penguin
B. squirrel
C. cardinal
D. polar bear

In the Adirondack forests of New York, some trees have died. The change in the forest is thought to be related to air pollution and rain. Which abiotic factor most likely has been changed as a result of the pollution and rain which resulted in the death of the trees?
A. a decrease in the amount of available oxygen
B. an increase in the amount of sunlight
C. a decrease in the pH of the soil
D. an increase in the nutrients
examples.target: C. a decrease in the pH of the soil

examples.input:
The Sun is classified as
A. an organism
B. a decomposer
C. a star
D. a planet

Which material is attracted to a magnet?
A. iron
B. wood
C. plastic
D. ice

What are the building blocks of all matter?
A. atoms
B. forces
C. cells
D. vacuoles

Mrs. Henry's class studied the arrangement of planets in the solar system. Which planets are closest to each other?
A. Mars and Earth
B. Saturn and Jupiter
C. Mercury and Venus
D. Uranus and Neptune

The primary role of the endocrine system is to
1. produce hormones that regulate body functions
2. form chemicals that destroy microbes
3. break down food to release nutrients
4. supply red blood cells to carry oxygen
examples.target: 1. produce hormones that regulate body functions

examples.input:
What happens when an animal hibernates?
A. There is no life in any of its parts.
B. It stops breathing.
C. Its temperature is higher than when it is active.
D. It is absorbing energy for use when it is active.
E. It is using less energy than when it is active.
examples.target: E. It is using less energy than when it is active.

examples.input:
The invention of the microscope was important to the advancement of science. Many other discoveries were only possible with the help of the microscope. The microscope was used to make which discovery?
A. Matter is made of elements.
B. Plants can make their own food.
C. Some organisms have only one cell.
D. White light can be broken into colors.
examples.target: C. Some organisms have only one cell.

examples.input:
A galaxy is best described as a cluster of
A. hundreds of stars.
B. thousands of stars.
C. millions of stars.
D. billions of stars.

A student in science class finds an unlabeled bottle containing a liquid. For safety purposes the student should
A. tell the teacher about the bottle and liquid.
B. pour the liquid down the drain.
C. compare the liquid to other liquids.
D. find the mass of the bottle and liquid.
examples.target: A. tell the teacher about the bottle and liquid.

examples.input:
A scientist discovered a way to turn plant material into fuel. This more cleanly burning fuel can be used in cars. How do people most likely benefit from turning plant material into fuel?
A. Cars are safer to drive.
B. Farmers grow more plants.
C. The amount of air pollution is reduced.
D. The number of cars around the world increases.
examples.target: C. The amount of air pollution is reduced.

examples.input:
Sunlight is able to penetrate the top several meters of marine water, where most plant and animal life exists. Which of these systems are interacting in this description?
A. solar energy and ocean systems
B. solar energy and weather systems
C. weather systems and ocean systems
D. solar energy, ocean systems, and weather systems
examples.target: A. solar energy and ocean systems

examples.input:
A male puppy inherits traits from
A. both parents
B. its mother, only
C. its father, only

Fossil fuels were made from specific kinds of ancient organisms. The fossilized remains of tiny ocean organisms formed
A. only coal.
B. only natural gas.
C. oil and coal.
D. oil and natural gas.

In the water cycle, where does water go after reaching the ocean?
A. The water flows into a river.
B. The water falls from the clouds.
C. The water sinks to the ocean floor.
D. The water changes into water vapor.
examples.target: D. The water changes into water vapor.

examples.input:
Mountain bike tires have large, knob-like treads. These tires are useful on steep slopes because they
A. increase friction.
B. carry heavy weights.
C. increase the stopping distance.
D. prevent braking of the bicycle.

A student plans to write a report about a type of bird that includes only facts. Which statement should the student leave out of the report?
A. These birds are blue.
B. These birds are beautiful.
C. Most of these birds are 13 cm tall.
D. Most of these birds are about 10 grams.

Over a long time, oil can form when layers of sediment push down on decomposing
A. trees.
B. animals.
C. fungi.
D. algae.

A biological community is made up of all the
1. populations living in an area
2. natural resources present in an area
3. members of a species on Earth
4. environments on Earth

Which temperature and moisture conditions describe an air mass that originates over the Atlantic Ocean near the equator?
1. warm and dry
2. warm and humid
3. cool and dry
4. cool and humid

The parts of plants that make seeds are the
A. roots.
B. stems.
C. flowers.
D. leaves.

Fossil fuels were formed from
A. uranium
B. sea water
C. sand and gravel
D. dead plants and animals

Over time, iron becomes rust when it combines with water and oxygen. Which type of change must occur for rust to form?
A. chemical
B. mechanical
C. nuclear
D. physical

When a bottle of strong perfume is opened at the front of a classroom, the smell gradually spreads throughout the entire room. Which process explains this occurrence?
A. osmosis
B. diffusion
C. cell activity
D. cell transport

A student is trying to model an ocean environment. What is the most important factor the student should add to the aquarium in order to make sure that the model is accurate?
A. starfish
B. seaweed
C. salt water
D. coral reef

Students measured how long it took for an ice cube to melt. Which measurement best represents how long it took for the ice cube to melt?
A. 20° Celsius
B. 40 grams
C. 60 milliliters
D. 80 seconds

Rocks are classified as sedimentary, metamorphic, or igneous on the basis of the
1. age of the rocks
2. way the rocks were formed
3. types of fossils the rocks contain
4. number of minerals found in the rocks

Which basic units of matter have the same properties as an element?
A. protons
B. electrons
C. atoms
D. neutrons

Some jet airplanes fly in a layer of the atmosphere where temperature generally increases with altitude. What is this layer of the atmosphere?
A. mesosphere
B. stratosphere
C. thermosphere
D. troposphere

One unique characteristic of water is that its specific heat
A. can only be measured in calories.
B. is lower than other common substances.
C. is higher than other common substances.
D. requires little energy for a big temperature change.
examples.target: C. is higher than other common substances.

examples.input:
An earthquake occurs in western Nevada. What most likely causes the earthquake?
A. stress due to the movement of Earth's crustal plates
B. gravitational variation due to the Moon's orbit around Earth
C. temperature variation due to Earth's orbit around the Sun
D. rotational imbalance due to changes in the location of Earth's poles
examples.target: A. stress due to the movement of Earth's crustal plates

examples.input:
A scientist puts more food than a lab rat can eat in each of 100 cages containing lab rats. She surveys the mass of food each rat eats in one day. To determine the difference between the largest and smallest masses of food eaten, she should find her data's
A. mean.
B. range.
C. mode.
D. median.

Which of these is defined as "the passage of genetic instructions from one generation to the next?"
A. growth
B. heredity
C. development
D. reproduction

What is the primary source of stored thermal energy in oceans?
A. sunlight
B. plankton
C. volcanoes
D. hurricanes

Two empty metal cans, one black and one white, were placed outside on a hot day. Both cans were the same size and were left in the Sun for 3 hours. Compared to the white can, the black can would most likely be
A. cooler, because it absorbs less sunlight
B. cooler, because it absorbs more sunlight
C. warmer, because it absorbs less sunlight
D. warmer, because it absorbs more sunlight
examples.target: D. warmer, because it absorbs more sunlight

examples.input:
Oil and gas are two sources of energy used in America. Which is the main reason oil and gas may be replaced with other sources of energy in the future?
A. Oil and gas produce very little power.
B. Oil and gas work in too few machines.
C. Oil and gas are limited in their supplies.
D. Oil and gas are too costly to remove from the ground.
examples.target: C. Oil and gas are limited in their supplies.

examples.input:
Which of these are parts of the geologic process that changes metamorphic rock into sedimentary rock?
A. volcanic eruption and lava flow
B. igneous intrusion and solidification
C. faulting and displacement
D. erosion and deposition

In a forest, a brown-colored bird sits on a tree branch. How does the bird's brown color most likely help it survive in the forest?
A. attracts insects for food
B. warns predators of its defense
C. hides it from predators
D. allows it to stay warm

Rock layers with sand-sized particles were most likely deposited by
A. wind.
B. water.
C. glaciers.
D. landslides.

The living systems of plants and animals are constantly taking in water to continue the processes of life. What eventually happens to most of that water?
A. It is converted into hydrogen and oxygen.
B. It is returned to the environment.
C. It is broken down by bacterial decay.
D. It is permanently combined with other compounds.
examples.target: B. It is returned to the environment.

examples.input:
MOST of the volcanoes that make up the "Ring of Fire" were formed near
A. hot spots.
B. subduction zones.
C. divergent boundaries.
D. normal faults.

Which is not considered an instrument to be used to determine weather?
A. a barometer
B. a thermometer
C. an anemometer
D. a millimeter

Which natural process is responsible for the formation of the Mississippi Delta?
A. snow
B. drought
C. deposition
D. weathering

Neon (Ne), argon (Ar), and krypton (Kr) are in the same column on the Periodic Table of the Elements. What characteristic do these elements have in common?
A. atomic mass
B. negative electrical charge
C. number of neutrons
D. full valence electron shells

Screech owls nest in holes in trees. They eat mice and crickets. Where would a screech owl most likely live?
A. a beach
B. a forest
C. a desert
D. a rainforest

Carlos was playing on a slide on a sunny summer day. Which property of the slide tells Carlos how much energy the slide absorbed from the Sun?
A. the mass
B. the color
C. the height
D. the temperature

Which equation summarizes the process of respiration?
A. water + carbon dioxide + energy -> sugar + oxygen
B. oxygen + sugar -> carbon dioxide + water + energy
C. carbon dioxide + oxygen + water -> sugar + energy
D. sugar + carbon dioxide + energy -> oxygen + water
examples.target: B. oxygen + sugar -> carbon dioxide + water + energy

examples.input:
When a baker bakes bread, he prepares the dough by mixing 2 cups of flour with 1 cup of water. The water needs to be 85°F. Which tools are best for the baker to measure both the volume and temperature of the water?
A. a balance and a ruler
B. a balance and a thermometer
C. a measuring cup and a balance
D. a measuring cup and a thermometer
examples.target: D. a measuring cup and a thermometer

examples.input:
What form of energy makes a compass needle point north?
A. electrical
B. heat
C. light
D. magnetic

Which process in the water cycle is directly caused by the heat from the Sun?
A. evaporation
B. runoff
C. cloud formation
D. stream flow

Which tool is used to observe the cell wall of a leaf?
A. ruler
B. camera
C. hand lens
D. microscope

Which material best conducts electricity?
A. wool coat
B. copper pipe
C. plastic straw
D. wooden stick

In 1922 N. L. Bowen developed the concept of magmatic evolution which is also known as Bowen's Reaction Series. Applying the Bowen's Series principles, what mineral forms and crystallizes first in the region of highest temperature and pressure?
A. olivine
B. pyroxene
C. amphibole
D. quartz

A cyclist travels 3 km north in 25 minutes. What does this information describe?
A. mass
B. force
C. motion
D. gravity

Which of these occurs when the North Pole is tilted toward the Sun and the United States has the most daylight hours of the year?
A. summer solstice
B. winter solstice
C. spring equinox
D. fall equinox

A ball rolls across the floor and slows down to a stop. Which force caused the ball to slow down?
A. friction
B. gravity
C. magnetic
D. inertia

Which energy source might involve burning wood or producing gasohol?
A. biomass
B. wind turbine
C. nuclear fission
D. hydroelectric power

A marine iguana is an animal that lives on the shoreline of warm islands. Its tail is long and thick. Which of these is improved by the shape of its tail?
A. swimming in the ocean
B. blending in with rocks
C. absorbing nutrients
D. finding food inland

Leslie's science teacher told her she must take a flexible approach to solving problems. What did Leslie's teacher most likely mean?
A. Leslie should not follow the experimental instructions exactly.
B. Leslie should only write down lab results that seem to be correct.
C. Leslie should accept all scientific theories even if they have been proven wrong.
D. Leslie should be willing to consider many possible causes for her observations.
examples.target: D. Leslie should be willing to consider many possible causes for her observations.

examples.input:
What would happen if a magnet was placed in the center of a plastic bowl containing a mixture of iron filings and sand?
A. The sand will be repelled by the magnet.
B. The iron filings will be attracted to the magnet.
C. The sand will be attracted to the magnet.
D. The iron filings will be repelled by the magnet.
examples.target: B. The iron filings will be attracted to the magnet.

examples.input:
Which property of an object is identified using the sense of smell?
A. color
B. odor
C. temperature
D. weight

Hector's class is counting the number of ducks in a pond. Hector counts a different number than the rest of the class. Which of the following actions should Hector most likely perform?
A. keep the result
B. change the number he counted
C. think that the class results are wrong
D. remove his number from the class result

Which property of sugar remains after sugar is dissolved in water?
A. color
B. taste
C. shape
D. texture

Which substance is composed of only one type of atom?
A. water
B. gold
C. salt
D. sugar

Over a two-week period, several students complain of feeling sick. Their symptoms include a cough, fever, and a sore throat. What describes the most likely cause of these symptoms?
A. exposure to hot weather
B. decrease in physical exercise
C. consumption of bad food
D. infection by a virus

The Appalachian Mountains, which extend from Canada to Alabama, were much taller in the past than they are today. Which of the following two processes are most responsible for the decrease in the height of the Appalachian Mountains?
A. weathering and erosion
B. sedimentation and flooding
C. volcanic eruptions and landslides
D. tectonic collisions and earthquakes

Which organisms break down and recycle dead plants and animals?
A. predators
B. prey
C. decomposers
D. producers

Which is not a significant reason why people are living longer today than 100 years ago?
A. development of sugar substitutes
B. development of medicines
C. better health care
D. better nutrition

Joann repeatedly overfed the fish in the pond behind her house. The nitrates from the excess food contributed to an overgrowth of algae. To correct the problem, Joann added more plants to the pond. How will adding more plants help?
A. The plants make the pond look beautiful.
B. The plants will camouflage the green algae.
C. The plants will compete with algae for nutrients.
D. The plants will provide all the food for the fish.
examples.target: C. The plants will compete with algae for nutrients.

examples.input:
The engineering team that is designing a scientific research station on the Arctic permafrost has to provide the station with energy for cooking, heating, and lighting. Considering the fragile environment and other conditions there, the best choice is probably to
A. build a wind turbine.
B. have fuel trucked in.
C. have a pipeline built.
D. build a solar collector.

A student walks to school each morning in Maine. It is dark outside when he begins walking. As the days pass, the student notices the mornings are becoming brighter. The Sun is rising earlier each day. He also notices that there is more daylight after school. The Sun is setting later in the day. Which change of seasons is occurring?
A. winter to spring
B. summer to fall
C. spring to winter
D. fall to winter

Where did organisms live when they first appeared on Earth?
A. in the water
B. in the air
C. on the land
D. under the ground

Which of the following will always produce a magnetic force on a nearby iron nail?
A. a long piece of copper wire
B. a large static electric charge
C. an electric current
D. an electric field

Which of these items is designed to produce heat from electricity?
A. a toaster
B. a camera
C. a blender
D. a television

A student records the temperature in the schoolyard every day for a month. Which is the best way to present the temperature data so each day can be compared?
A. summary paragraph
B. labeled diagram
C. pie chart
D. bar graph

At approximately which time of day is the Sun at the highest point in the sky to an observer in New York State?
A. 6 a.m.
B. noon
C. 6 p.m.
D. midnight

When one form of energy is converted into other forms of energy, the total amount of energy
A. varies throughout the conversion.
B. increases because some energy is created.
C. remains constant throughout the conversion.
D. decreases because some energy is destroyed.
examples.target: C. remains constant throughout the conversion.

examples.input:
To study the effect of heat on plant growth, Andy divided ten identical seedlings into groups. She placed one group on a windowsill in the sun and the other group in a dark closet on the cool (north) side of the house. Think about the characteristics of a properly designed scientific experiment. What is wrong with the above experiment?
A. The temperature difference between the two groups was not great enough.
B. The amount of light was different for the two groups.
C. One group of seedlings got less water than the other.
D. Nothing is wrong with the experiment.
examples.target: B. The amount of light was different for the two groups.

examples.input:
Which of these groups would be most concerned with technological developments in insect control?
A. paleontologists
B. archaeologists
C. agriculturists
D. meteorologists

A model of Earth would be different from a model of the Moon because the Moon model would be
A. shinier
B. heavier
C. smaller
D. rougher

A student sees a bird at a feeder. The student identifies the bird as a sparrow. Which organ system did the student use to identify the bird?
A. circulatory
B. muscular
C. nervous
D. skeletal

Which tool is the best to use when studying small organisms not visible to the eye?
A. telescope
B. hand lens
C. microscope
D. magnifying glass

Which would most likely cause a decrease in the number of woodpeckers in an ecosystem?
A. draining a spring-fed pond
B. plowing and planting meadows
C. destroying all dead trees and stumps
D. building a road around a small forest
examples.target: C. destroying all dead trees and stumps

examples.input:
Which is not a characteristic common to organisms?
A. requires energy
B. reproduction
C. rigidity
D. presence of DNA

Which calculation is used to determine acceleration?
A. divide change in velocity by change in time
B. multiply average velocity by change in time
C. divide average velocity by mass
D. multiply change in velocity by distance traveled
examples.target: A. divide change in velocity by change in time

examples.input:
Dogs have some learned behaviors. Which is most likely a learned behavior in a dog?
A. sniffing to find food
B. panting when it feels hot
C. chasing a squirrel up a tree
D. barking when it wants to go outside
examples.target: D. barking when it wants to go outside

examples.input:
Some wasp species lay their eggs inside living caterpillars. As the eggs mature, they use the caterpillar as a food resource. Eventually, the wasp larvae hatch out of the caterpillar. This type of relationship is best described as
A. predator-prey.
B. parasitic.
C. mutualistic.
D. commensalistic.

Which is the best action to help protect water resources in Virginia?
A. Dispose of pet waste in a stream.
B. Rinse spilled gasoline with a hose.
C. Organize a river cleanup program.
D. Put hazardous waste in with house trash.
examples.target: C. Organize a river cleanup program.

examples.input:
The Moon's rotation is
A. faster than its revolution.
B. slower than its revolution.
C. half as fast as its revolution.
D. about the same as its revolution.
examples.target: D. about the same as its revolution.

examples.input:
Which process involves choosing certain organisms to reproduce with one another in order to pass on specific, desirable traits to their offspring?
1. selective breeding
2. asexual reproduction
3. resource acquisition
4. natural selection

During which process are nuclei duplicated?
A. mitosis
B. respiration
C. photosynthesis
D. fertilization

In a turtle race, each turtle walks one a 3-meter track. If the turtles walk one at a time, how can you tell which turtle was fastest?
A. The turtle that started first is fastest.
B. The turtle that finished first is fastest.
C. The turtle that took the shortest time is fastest.
D. The turtle that took the longest time is fastest.
examples.target: C. The turtle that took the shortest time is fastest.

examples.input:
Which organism is a decomposer?
A. frog
B. worm
C. oak tree
D. grasshopper

Parents with freckles often have children with freckles. This occurs because
A. freckles develop from light.
B. certain foods cause freckles.
C. certain habits cause freckles.
D. freckles are an inherited trait.
examples.target: D. freckles are an inherited trait.

examples.input:
Two fossils of the same species were found on two different continents. The continents are separated by the Atlantic Ocean. Scientists dated the fossils to be 2 million years old. Which is the least likely explanation for these findings?
A. A great land bridge once connected the continents.
B. The remains were carried by ocean currents.
C. A single landmass once existed with both continents.
D. The animals swam across the ocean.
examples.target: B. The remains were carried by ocean currents.

examples.input:
Students visited a garden to observe hummingbirds. They wanted to find out if hummingbirds were more likely to visit colored flowers or white flowers. Which should the students do first for this investigation?
A. conclude that hummingbirds prefer white flowers
B. write a report about the kinds of flowers in the garden
C. observe hummingbirds at flowers and record the flower color
D. research the number of different hummingbirds that live in the garden
examples.target: C. observe hummingbirds at flowers and record the flower color

examples.input:
What is the name of the author who proposed natural selection as the mechanism of evolution?
A. Mendel
B. Darwin
C. Lamarck
D. Hardy-Weinberg

Which pair of terms describes the usual location for fertilization and the first stages of development in human reproduction?
1. external fertilization and external development
2. external fertilization and internal development
3. internal fertilization and external development
4. internal fertilization and internal development

In the rock cycle an igneous rock forms from
A. cooling temperatures
B. high pressure and heat
C. weathering and erosion
D. compacted plant remains

Mars is an inner planet and Jupiter is an outer planet. Which best describes the relationship between the two planets?
A. They are made of the same materials.
B. They orbit the Sun in opposite directions.
C. They have the same orbital periods around the Sun.
D. They are located on opposite sides of the asteroid belt.
examples.target: D. They are located on opposite sides of the asteroid belt.

examples.input:
In order for electricity from a battery to power a light bulb, the wire has to provide the electricity a path to do what?
A. flow through the entire closed circuit
B. charge the air molecules near the circuit
C. jump from one battery terminal to the other
D. change the chemical properties of the wire
examples.target: A. flow through the entire closed circuit

examples.input:
Many cities encourage people to recycle. The items that can be recycled are placed in a special container and picked up each week from people's homes. How does recycling most likely help the environment?
A. Recycling reduces littering.
B. Recycling makes products last longer.
C. Recycling puts less trash in the city landfill.
D. Recycling increases the amount of dust in the air.
examples.target: C. Recycling puts less trash in the city landfill.

examples.input:
When coal burns, the reaction
A. releases heat and is endothermic.
B. releases heat and is exothermic.
C. absorbs heat and is endothermic.
D. absorbs heat and is exothermic.
examples.target: B. releases heat and is exothermic.

examples.input:
Scientists have discovered that there has been a reduction in the butterfly population in an ecosystem. After much research, they have identified that the carrying capacity for butterflies has been decreased. If the scientists want to increase the butterfly population, which action should they recommend?
A. removing primary producers
B. spraying of insecticides
C. increasing runoff
D. planting flowers

Which do meteorologists use to measure the amount of precipitation that falls during a storm?
A. Anemometer
B. Barometer
C. Rain gauge
D. Weather vane

Which terms are both used to describe the weather?
A. gravity and wind direction
B. precipitation and runoff
C. groundwater and erosion
D. air temperature and wind speed
examples.target: D. air temperature and wind speed

examples.input:
Which of these has been controlled in an attempt to reduce the depletion of ozone in Earth's atmosphere?
A. methods of filtering gasoline
B. use of chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs)
C. methods of radioactive waste storage
D. use of mercury (Hg) compounds

Today's limestone caverns were once solid rock. Acidic rainwater seeping through the rock over hundreds of years dissolved part of the rock, forming caverns. This is an example of
A. erosion.
B. deposition.
C. physical weathering.
D. chemical weathering.

Which of the following contains most of the water on Earth?
A. the oceans
B. watersheds
C. the atmosphere
D. ice and aquifers

Which substance do all living things require to survive?
1. blood
2. water
3. carbon dioxide
4. organic soil

A student plans to measure the thermal expansion of a strip of metal as it is heated from 0ºC to 50ºC. Which piece of equipment should he use to measure the expansion?
A. a ruler
B. a balance
C. a compass
D. a protractor

Which of these was used by Alfred Wegener as evidence that Earth's continental landmasses had drifted apart over time?
A. the age of the continents
B. the shape of the continents
C. the thickness of the continents
D. the composition of the continents
examples.target: B. the shape of the continents

examples.input:
The driver of a car at a railroad crossing hears a change in pitch of the train whistle as the train passes by. This change in pitch is most likely due to
A. the Doppler effect.
B. the Compton effect.
C. a change in medium.
D. a change in speed.

Which is an example of a hypothesis?
A. Large mice will eat more food than smaller mice.
B. One flower was measured to be 13 centimeters tall.
C. On a dark night, a student counted hundreds of stars.
D. People should be careful to protect endangered animals.
examples.target: A. Large mice will eat more food than smaller mice.

examples.input:
Which would be considered an inexhaustible resource?
A. oil
B. topsoil
C. sunlight
D. aluminum

Which factor causes surface ocean currents?
A. the Sun
B. the wind
C. the Moon
D. hurricanes

Marta has a radio in her room. It requires electricity in order to play. Which of the following is necessary in order for electricity to move from the source to the radio?
A. a circuit
B. a magnet
C. a light bulb
D. an insulator

Having dry, hot weather for a long time can cause a
A. drought
B. thunderstorm
C. tornado
D. flood

What is the primary function of white blood cells in humans?
A. carry oxygen
B. fight disease
C. grow tissues
D. remove waste

Which trait most likely helps an animal survive in a very cold environment?
A. long ears
B. large eyes
C. thick fur
D. sharp claws

Which is most likely a genetic adaptation of desert plants to survive the hot, dry climate conditions?
A. thin bark
B. waxy leaves
C. leaves that remain all year
D. flowers that bloom all year

Charles Darwin made a number of observations and inferences during his travels. He studied island finches during a long period of time. Which statement is an inference?
A. Individual birds have different colored feathers.
B. Island finches have a large number of offspring.
C. Individual birds of an island finch species have many differences.
D. Island finches share a common ancestry with mainland finch species.
examples.target: D. Island finches share a common ancestry with mainland finch species.

examples.input:
A student mixes salt and water in a beaker to form a solution. What properties of the substances would allow the student to then separate the components?
A. densities
B. particle sizes
C. boiling points
D. electrical conductivity

In a lab investigation, students had to identify different mineral specimens. Which property is the most reliable for identifying one mineral from another?
A. texture
B. hardness
C. crystal shape
D. surface color

Which of these revolves around a planet?
A. an asteroid.
B. a star.
C. a comet.
D. a moon.

A scientist wants to collect several bird eggs on an island. She needs a case that will protect the eggs she collects. Which of the following cases would best protect the eggs?
A. a hard metal case with flexible foam lining
B. a flexible metal case with smooth plastic lining
C. a strong wooden case with lightweight plastic lining
D. a lightweight wooden case with strong aluminum lining
examples.target: A. a hard metal case with flexible foam lining

examples.input:
Which process is a cause of variation in a species?
1. metamorphosis
2. cellular respiration
3. sexual reproduction
4. regulation

The leaves of a tree change color in the fall. This is an example of a tree
A. completing its life cycle
B. preparing for migration
C. responding to its environment
D. beginning hibernation

A dog growls when a predator gets close. Growling is an example of which animal behavior?
A. migration
B. hibernation
C. communication
D. germination

In what respect are protons and electrons always equal?
A. mass number
B. kinetic energy
C. sign of charge
D. magnitude of charge

How does the Sun help move water from the ocean through the water cycle?
A. by causing surface water to evaporate
B. by adding particles to the water
C. by increasing the amount of water
D. by blowing water toward land
examples.target: A. by causing surface water to evaporate

examples.input:
What would a model of the Sun, Earth, and Moon best help students visualize?
A. the phases of the Moon
B. the effects of gravitation
C. the effects of volcanic eruptions
D. the consequences of earthquakes
examples.target: A. the phases of the Moon

examples.input:
How are bacterial cells and human cells alike?
A. They allow oxygen through the cell wall.
B. They allow carbon dioxide through the cell wall.
C. They allow nutrients through the cell membrane.
D. They allow nutrients through the nuclear membrane.
examples.target: C. They allow nutrients through the cell membrane.

examples.input:
The Moon's surface is visible to an observer on Earth because the Moon
1. reflects sunlight
2. absorbs light from Earth
3. produces its own light
4. transmits sunlight

Why do trees like oaks and walnuts depend upon squirrels?
A. to control population size
B. to pollinate their flowers
C. to remove dead wood
D. to aid in seed distribution
examples.target: D. to aid in seed distribution

examples.input:
When an atom gains an electron, the atom will
A. lose a proton.
B. reduce its mass.
C. become radioactive.
D. have a negative charge.

A paramecium is an example of
A. a single-celled organism.
B. multiple organisms.
C. an inorganic substance.
D. a group of cells.

A sea anemone uses poisonous darts to
A. absorb food.
B. defend itself.
C. attract a mate.
D. protect its young.

Rivers and streams can carry sediments long distances before they are deposited. What is formed when sediments are deposited at the mouth of a river?
A. a levee
B. a gully
C. a delta
D. a rift

Steel is used for cables in suspension bridges because of its capacity for
A. tension.
B. torsion.
C. compression.
D. contraction.
